name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I declare the session suspended on Wednesday, 11 November 2015, to be resumed.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which Ten days ago, France was attacked in the most brutal way. Terrorists who, on an unprecedented scale, have, with unprecedented brutality, ripped ordinary people, especially young men and women, out of their lives and murdered them in a bestial manner. Today, as an institution based in France, we are on French soil for the first time since these attacks. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, by thanking all of you for your great sympathy over the past week in the expressions of condolences here, I repeat once again our full solidarity with the French nation, our attention to the families of those who have been murdered, our hope for the seriously injured people that they will soon recover. However, this also applies to the victims of the attacks in Bamako. This also applies to the victims of the attacks in other places where innocent people are slaughtered by insane terrorists. Ladies and gentlemen! We live in a time of enormous challenges. The number of attacks that we should remember here because we cannot make a hierarchy in the list of victims and each victim is worth the same to us – this list is long. That is why a commemoration of the victims in Paris and in Bamako is at the same time a commemoration of the victims, of the innocent in other places on the planet, and especially in Syria and Iraq, where this self-proclaimed Islamic State is trying to destroy all basic rights, almost civilisational values, with its brutality. Every commemoration is a tribute to the victims of this violence. In this sense, not only for the victims of Paris and Bamako, but for the victims of terrorism as a whole, I ask you to rise from your seats. (The House rose and observed a minute's silence) Thank you very much. Ladies and gentlemen! This morning I had the sad duty to represent the European Parliament at the State Act for the late former Federal Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, Helmut Schmidt. With Helmut Schmidt, an outstanding politician died not only of the Federal Republic of Germany, but of the European Union. Helmut Schmidt, as you all know, was one of the creators of the European Monetary System, in particular with former President Valéry Giscard d'Estaing. Schmidt made a huge contribution to deepening European integration and to cooperation between peoples across borders during his time as head of government, but also later as a publicist. Helmut Schmidt was a head of government who, in the country from which I come, in the country from which I come, maintained a principle from which, I believe, we can learn today, a principle best expressed in Albert Camus's sentence: "Those who fail in the reconciliation of freedom and security fail in everything." I believe that this should guide us for the next challenges ahead. We must make the security of our citizens, including our own, as effective as possible. But we must never allow those who want to frighten us to destroy our freedoms. That is the task of the European Parliament in particular. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The final draft agenda for this part-session, as set out in the Conference of Presidents at its meeting on Thursday 19 November 2015 in accordance with Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed.  Monday: The GUE/NGL Group requests that the debate on the oral question to the Commission on a new animal welfare strategy for the period 2016 to 2020 be concluded with a resolution, which can then be voted on on Thursday.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, under Rule 152 of the Rules of Procedure, I urge Parliament to close the debate on Oral Question O—000141/2015 on a new animal welfare strategy for 2016–2020 with a resolution. The current animal welfare strategy ends on 31 December and the Commission shows no sign of coming forward with a new strategy. This is unacceptable. There are many issues concerning animal welfare in the European Union which should be addressed, and we want the Commission to come forward with a clear roadmap to do that. Also, on behalf of my colleague, Stefan Eck, I ask for your support to add this resolution to close the debate. If you think animals matter, this is the time to show it.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: – Mr President, I wish to thank Madam Hazekamp for her initiative. There have been many bills – much legislation – passed in this House in recent years, but they are not coherent, there is no complete strategy and there is not even a cohesive legislative framework within the European Union today. That means also that the animals are suffering; it means that we have different regulations in different countries, and it also means that we do not have, when it comes to agricultural products, a joint and common market. I therefore support the proposition from the GUE/NGL Group.

name: Michèle ALLIOT-MARIE
text: Mr President, let me just make a comparison. Our group has called for Parliament to adopt a resolution following the debate on the terrorist attacks in Paris, asking the Commission what it intends to do to effectively implement all the measures that have been adopted without ever being implemented and which may have saved hundreds of lives. I would be a little surprised if, in the European Parliament, it is believed that a resolution for animal welfare, which I fully support, comes before a resolution for the survival of men and women. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mrs Alliot-Marie, compliment, you spoke with a clever wording in favour of the motion, even though you had spoken against it, and you also made your protest. A la bonne heure! Colleagues want an electronic review. (Parliament adopted the motion) Tuesday: No changes. Wednesday: The Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance requests that the vote on the Ferreira/Theurer report on tax rulings and other measures be postponed until Thursday.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, this Parliament has decided to make the fight against abusive corporate tax optimisation an important issue since it set up a special committee to deal with this issue last February. We will vote this week on the first report of this committee. I believe it will be adopted by a very large majority and I welcome that.  Our concern is this: at its meeting last week, the Conference of Presidents decided, by a majority, to postpone by at least a week the decision to present to our house a possible extension of the Tax Committee, which was in any case the subject of a very broad consensus among the political forces. We did not want to give the impression that we were going to adopt the commission's report and then decide later whether we would extend its mandate. We thought it was important to combine the two decisions so as not to create the impression among the public that this Parliament is not interested in the issue. In the meantime, I have received very clear messages from different political groups , and therefore from the majority, which is in favour of the extension, that the Conference of Presidents could take a decision on Thursday and put it to the vote of this assembly on Thursday at noon. In that case, the problem would disappear and we could adopt the report on Wednesday and vote on the extension of the commission on Thursday. There was doubt about this at the previous Conference of Presidents, but if this doubt is removed and the political commitment is made to extend the Tax Committee, there is no reason to delay the vote.  That is the position of our group.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the More than a year ago, LuxLeaks became aware of the scandalous tax deals of international corporations with EU Member States. Every village policeman knows that investigations cannot be completed until all the evidence has been assessed. However, we have been systematically denied access to important documents. Only here in Parliament has this not been so clear to everyone. That's why we had a lot of back and forth last week. That is why I am also calling for the vote to be postponed, call it an interim report, whatever. The current mandate must not expire and must be extended this week. The agenda must be amended accordingly. Otherwise, we will be totally implausible here in the fight against tax havens.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I would ask for an explanation because I understood the member, the Green party's candidate, that the motion would be withdrawn when there is a clear commitment that we will all support the extension in plenary. On behalf of my group, I can say that the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats wants the extension of the six months to clarify precisely the outstanding issues that are still in the pipeline. In this respect, the basis for this would be lost if other groups confirmed that we are clearly committing ourselves on Thursday to supporting the extension. Then we can hold the vote as normal on Wednesday. That is how I think I understood my colleague. And we as a group would like to clarify the outstanding issues.

name: Peter SIMON
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I have been asked to say on behalf of the Socialist Group that, even in the event of all the unrest that has arisen, it is naturally in favour of voting on the Ferreira report on Wednesday, that this should be dealt with in the Conference of Presidents on Thursday and that it should be decided here in plenary on Thursday lunchtime to extend the committee.  In this respect, I am grateful to Mr Lamberts for withdrawing the motion.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: (The applicant withdrew the application)) (The order of business has therefore been adopted.)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission's statement on the state of play of the Doha Development Agenda in the light of the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference (2015/2632(RSP)."

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, there are now only three weeks left until the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference in Nairobi. This will mark the WTO’s 20th anniversary and it is the first such conference taking place in Africa. This is a conference that is taking place at a critical moment for the WTO. Following the success of the last such conference in Bali and the adoption of the Trade Facilitation Agreement, there were high hopes that we would advance towards a comprehensive agreement on the Doha Development Agenda, and the EU worked really hard to achieve this. Unfortunately, many countries have not been able or willing to look for a compromise on cutting the trade-distorting subsidies they provide to their farmers. In Nairobi we need to free the machinery of the WTO from the constraints that have been holding it back for so many years. We need to move ahead. The Ministerial Conference needs to take decisions on parts of the Doha Round and agree on what to do next. We are now working in Geneva intensively to create convergence around three main outcomes that are attainable and where we all see that there are development credentials. The first one is to aim for an agreement to discipline the use of all forms of agricultural export support, which is an important long-standing and pro-development issue that needs a coherent, balanced and multilateral solution. Together with the Government of Brazil and a few other WTO members, the European Union has tabled a formal proposal for a comprehensive solution addressing agricultural export subsidies, but also export credits and other similar measures. I am convinced that this is a good basis for discussion and a compromise, and it also showcases the positive effects of the major agricultural reforms that we have been conducting here in the EU. Without them, it would have been impossible to achieve a situation where we table a joint agricultural proposal with Brazil. So we are now working on this in Geneva to gather support. Secondly, we also need to make sure that we can deliver for the benefit of the poorest and most vulnerable WTO members: the least-developed countries. Here we are looking at, for instance, duty-free; quota-free; cotton; rules of origin. The third item where we need to deliver is an outcome strengthening notification and transparency requirements in the WTO. Achieving consensus on these issues will be linked to the need for an agreement on the path forward for the WTO after the Ministerial Conference. This is going to be challenging. Our interests here are very clear. The WTO needs to continue the work on unresolved issues. They can only be effectively addressed by multilateral solutions – trade-distorting domestic support in agriculture, rules or regulatory issues, for instance – but we need to approach these issues with fresh ideas, as the old approaches have clearly not delivered the result, and in this connection large emerging countries must assume greater responsibilities. Similarly, we need to aim to ensure that the Ministerial Conference begins the process of opening the Organization to considering new issues and acknowledges the possibilities for WTO members to negotiate issues within smaller groups of interested members. This is really important if the WTO is to remain relevant and at the centre of global rule—making. The upcoming Ministerial Conference will be a very important event. It will have a strong bearing on the future of the multilateral trading system. I appreciate very much the cooperation we have had so far and the interest that this Parliament has taken, and I am looking forward to Parliament’s delegation being there so we can have close cooperation at the Ministerial Conference.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, let me first congratulate the co-chairman of this resolution, Mr Lange, on the fruitful cooperation we have had. The Commissioner and her team, whose fruitful work, as she has highlighted, also result in this Resolution.  In the European Union, in the European People's Party we have always made a firm commitment to multilateralism and obviously the right framework to carry it out is undoubtedly the World Trade Organisation. An approach that, as demonstrated by agreements such as the Trade Facilitation Agreement, seeks in particular to improve the economic situation of all its member countries. Because let us have no doubt: the greater trade openness, the greater the economic development. There are many examples that prove it. Here I think it should be noted that the Ministerial Conference to be held in Nairobi, as the Commissioner rightly stressed, is going to be a turning point that we all want and we will all contribute to it being for the better, because we need economic growth, we need job creation, now more than ever.  Nor should we forget that multilateralism must not only coexist, but must also be complemented by bilateral agreements, regional agreements and plurilateral agreements through which trade is being liberalized around the world. Agreements such as the ACS, agreements such as TTE or the agreement with Mercosur are now more than ever vital to the Union's trade agenda, because they can complement and can also promote the work of the World Trade Organization in areas where multilateralism cannot be achieved.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. First of all, i much thank you to the co-rapporteur, Mr Zalba Bidegain. I wonder whether the lights will be cleared for the WTO in Nairobi. Because there are those who want the Doha Development Round to stop talking about the Doha Development Round at all in Nairobi. I cannot see that we can develop the Doha Development Round and the WTO further and also develop a work programme beyond Nairobi, as the Commissioner has just mentioned, if we do not bring a positive link to the Doha Development Round into these negotiations. When some people say' 'Doha is dead, we just need to look at new elements – e-commerce, investment, the issue of currency speculation' – yes, ladies and gentlemen, then the wedge is being driven further towards division. So let us try to move forward multilaterally and give a positive assessment of the Doha Development Round in the 2008 package. Of course, we need sharpening, we need flexibility, we certainly also need the level of opportunity to go further bilaterally and plurilaterally. But the fact that we need to put development first is quite clear in view of the migration challenge. It is also clear that developing countries are not equal to developing countries. We must also be honest: emerging countries have a different level of responsibility, and they must take advantage of it. Everyone has to take responsibility.

name: Emma McCLARKIN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I believe that trade reduces poverty, empowers women and provides opportunities for our young people. We live in a globalised world and our citizens and consumers want the barriers to trade removed. It is therefore difficult to hide my disappointment that we have, once again, failed to make progress within the WTO ahead of the 10th ministerial meeting next month. It appears that this meeting will be something of a damp squib, with a real danger that the parties will not even manage to produce a joint statement following the discussions in Nairobi. It is clear that the Doha Development Agenda has failed, yet somehow we must press ahead with the multilateral agenda and the important issues contained within it. As the Commissioner mentioned, agricultural issues continue to be the most difficult problems to solve when it comes to international trade agreements. Yet it is important to recognise some of the other ambitions that Doha was looking to meet, such as efforts towards making it easier for developing countries to gain access to the international trading market, in turn providing real opportunities for economic development. Instead, we have to make progress in areas that we are able to agree upon – but it looks likely that this will have to come under the framework of a different agreement. So we need a new reinvigorated agenda at the WTO level – one which is not associated with the failures of the past and which can build from the bottom up so that we may look upon the WTO as an organisation that works in the interests of its members. Until then, parties will be forced to work at the bilateral and plurilateral levels, which will be essential to maintain growth and jobs in this globalised world. Within this, the EU must use the influence that it has so that we can push this multilateral agenda forward to achieve real success for all. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – Ms McClarkin, is not this debate an example of how little influence the United Kingdom has, bearing in mind that all trade negotiations are currently conducted with the EU Trade Commissioner, Ms Malmström, sitting at the front? Does this not show that Britain would have greater influence in the wider world were we to decide to withdraw from the European Union following the referendum?

name: Emma McCLARKIN
text: blue-card answer. – The British people will decide whether they believe they should remain a member of the European Union or not very soon and, indeed, if we have those trading powers back, we will be able to do deals ourselves. But the reality is that if we want to work towards trade for all and improve the work for everybody, it will have to be done at the World Trade Organization (WTO) level.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, it is indeed the case that the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference in December is really important to us, and it will show once and for all how progress can be made with the Doha Development Agenda package and whether it will come into force.  We are prepared to continue negotiations on the DDA, but I can say that a new basis is needed, because this current base has not produced any results, but a more active approach is now needed.  After all, this has not been about the European Union. We have been strongly in favour of Doha and we are still actively speaking out in favour of this package, but we should also get other partners involved. The entry into force of the DDA would be absolutely to be supported from the point of view of international trade, because we should create international rules for trade instead of regional rules. Common international rules would provide certainty in this area, as a number of bilateral agreements are now fragmenting regulation.  It would also be important from our point of view to resolve the DDA because we are also discussing the themes that are absolutely important to us. Even if we did not have a solution in the form of Doha, we would continue to negotiate on the same themes, but possibly separately with more than one party.  It is, of course, important that multilateral negotiations can also take place, then we can get to the next level of talking about content as well.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Commissioner, Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work and for the work she has done German Secretary of State Machnig publicly annoyed himself about having to travel to Africa just before Christmas for the WTO Ministerial Conference in Nairobi. It would already be clear that only one mouse would be born there. It was not the Europeans and the OECD who were to blame, but the Indians and Brazilians were once again slowing down. If you travel to Nairobi and really only have the old concepts of free trade in your luggage, you are wasting time. 60 million refugees in the world highlight the serious impact of the mistakes in international trade policy since the wto was founded. They cannot and cannot accuse India of at least this one country finding the food of its own people more important than free trade and rejecting speculation with food in the globalised markets. No, Pascal Lamy is quite agreeable when he calls for the WTO to finally integrate its work into the objectives of governments, civil society and international organisations.  The Doha Round was once intended to overcome poverty that led to the recruitment of the terrorists of 09/11. The fact that this goal was forgotten too quickly is a reminder of what is happening.  In Nairobi, the fundamental change of course must be discussed with regard to the objectives and mechanisms of international trade policy and its rules. No more, but no less! It is about the future of the multilateral partnership world trade system, and it is about the prospects and a 'yes' to Doha.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the My group stands for fair trade. Unlike free trade, we believe that there must be a fair forum, a global forum where trading partners – strong and weak – sit around the table and work together to find solutions that benefit all trading partners. We in the EU are undoubtedly a strong trading partner with a great deal of influence. We do not believe that it is desirable for world trade – and for the people of the EU – to impose our free trade agenda on weak trading partners. And we are not alone in this view. To this end, the World Trade Organisation also has special and differentiated treatment for all developing countries as a programme item. As a result, developing countries will be given market access and improved conditions, while at the same time being able to build up the domestic economy largely without the risk of foreign imports. With our resolution, on the other hand, you are calling for developing countries to be divided into certain categories, thereby opening up more to those countries which have been able to improve their economies in recent decades through these and other measures. We strongly oppose such a split, which would benefit the strongest trading partners the most. The resolution reaffirms support for multilateral approaches to world trade, but at the same time supports plurilateral agreements such as TiSA, which undermine the WTO and do not complement the WTO agenda, as claimed. With the far-reaching market access provisions in these agreements, we are depifting the rich countries with any incentive to conclude the Doha Round seriously and in line with developing countries. Doha must not become a friss-or-die round of negotiations! We call on the Commission to accommodate the developing countries. We have therefore tabled a number of amendments in order to make our resolution fairer and more objective. I hope that this approach will be supported. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – I noticed during your speech that you spoke about concern about weaker trading partners and developing countries. Would you not accept that one of the things that holds back developing countries is tariff controls and blocks from trading blocs such as the EU, as well as the unfair advantages given to the EU by the Common Agricultural Policy? If we had a fairer system and could trade freely, then we could have trade with developing countries, rather than aid as we have now.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. It is right to be able to offer our agricultural products on terms that are not available in developing countries. In other words, many of the plurilateral agreements that are bilateral are seriously disrupting the domestic agricultural economy. In this respect, I must agree with you. But that does not affect the rest of what I said.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, to get one thing in perspective: the European Union began as a protectionist construct, it remains a protectionist construct, it will always be a protectionist construct. Doha or no Doha, the European Union is a roadblock to free and freer trade. To give one example, which was just previously touched upon, European protectionism in food production has direct consequences which harm the developing world. First, the EU markets are closed to a greater or lesser extent to the export of agricultural products. Secondly, and more damagingly, the European Union dumps agricultural over-production, occasioned by its misallocated agricultural subsidies, onto the world market, and the effect of this is that farmers and food growers in the world outside – especially in those countries that have a large primary sector – are severely damaged. The people adversely affected are some of the poorest in the world. This is not fair trade. There are also other consequences. EU protectionism hurts and harms consumers in the European Union itself. Consumers here have to pay the hiked and inflated European Union price for foods and other goods instead of the world price. Professor Patrick Minford and his colleagues at Cardiff University have calculated that the cost of this to the UK consumer is 8% of the cost of living. It follows that, on Brexit, the cost of living in the UK would be reduced by 8% at least. We may be sure that in other Member States the figure would not be dissimilar. And so it is not just for my country: the dissolution of the EU customs union would be a huge plus for the whole world. That, perhaps, is what we should bear in mind when we are discussing the Doha agenda. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: blue-card question. – I would like to ask the Earl of Dartmouth if he is really so naive as to think that all the subsidies of the EU Member States would disappear if the European Union were suddenly abolished. Is it not more likely that the sum of all of these Member States would result in higher tariffs, as it is a fact that the two European countries that are not members of the European Union – Switzerland and Norway – actually have higher tariffs on agriculture and higher subsidies for agriculture?

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: blue-card answer. – Firstly, there are, of course, many countries which are not members of the European Union, as well as Switzerland and Norway. But the fact of the matter is that if there are subsidies – and particularly agricultural subsidies – these are much better determined at national level. If they were determined at national level, it is much more probable that the interest of the consumer would be heeded.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, today we are discussing the World Trade Organisation and how it, in cooperation with the other similar organisations, will be able to save the world from poverty.  Only for us, all these organisations are part of the problem and one of its main causes and they are obviously not part of the solution.  Advocates of economic and social liberalism want global trade relations to be defined through supranational organisations with the least possible intervention by states. Governments are the only ones that, albeit to a small extent, are somewhat controlled by citizens. On the contrary, these supranational organisations simply transfer power to multinationals and large capital while pretending to care and trying to protect peoples. In fact, it is these organisations that are promoting the liberalisation of markets from all kinds of obstacles and control with disastrous results for workers and for entire societies. Moreover, small and medium-sized enterprises are collapsing, powerless to confront the expansion of large groups actively supported by the World Trade Organisation, at the same time as everyone pretends to care about them. But unable to hide its true face, it is not enough for the World Trade Organisation to control the economic activity of all states. It seeks to impose their views on every aspect of society, on public administration management, tax policy, education, social policies and institutional reforms. Well, no facilitation for international usury capital, no concessions to those who destroy nations and peoples for money.  For us Greek nationalists, the only positive move the World Trade Organisation could make would be to dissolve itself.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Mr. President, I would like to first congratulate my colleagues Pablo Zalba Bidegain and Bernd Lange on the quality proposal for a resolution. Trade liberalisation is an important tool for achieving sustainable economic growth, and international trade could become the most important external source of financing for development for least developed countries. The importance of trade for sustainable development was also recognised in the recently adopted Agenda 2030 for Sustainable Development, where trade has been highlighted as an important tool for achieving new sustainable development goals and inclusive and sustainable development.  It is symbolic that the 10th WTO Ministerial Conference is being held for the first time in Africa, whose development is crucial for us in the European Union. The EU has always advocated and emphasised its commitment to multilateralism, while recognising complementary approaches and interim solutions such as bilateral, regional and plulilateral agreements that can significantly boost trade opening.  But to achieve at least some positive result of this WTO ministerial conference, it is also necessary to identify differences between least developed countries and those rapidly growing middle-income economies. The latter must take greater responsibility for further trade liberalisation as well as the achievement of the 2030 Agenda sustainable development goals. We must also pay attention to the conclusions of the 5th Trade Aid Review Conference, which focused mainly on the trade facilitation agreement, which seeks to help developing countries improve their trade capacity. Only improved customs procedures could, for example, increase global GDP by EUR 68 billion per year, with developing countries benefiting the most.  I therefore welcome the fact that the resolution calls on all WTO members to urgently address the ratification and implementation of this agreement so that it can enter into force before the WTO's 10th Ministerial Conference. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to ask my colleague Mr Stier that we are aware that trade facilitation will bring greater prosperity to developing countries. But it is precisely the Aid for Trad programme that is actually important, above all, to focus on the countries where the flow of refugees is now coming from. Does he believe that this discussion is now possible in Kenya and that we are giving all the support to the countries here in order to give people the opportunity to stay in their homeland again?

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear colleague, of course, I agree with you and what you asked, which is something that may be indirect, but also in this motion of resolution stands out.  When I was saying that emphasis must also be placed on this trade facilitation agreement where it helps developing countries to be able to increase their trade capacity, thereby better combating poverty and ensuring that people can and do have the right to stay in their country and have perspective there instead of having to migrate.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, my full support for the resolution and the excellent work of its rapporteurs, Bernd Lange and Pablo Zalba.  I want to say loud and clear that the European Union continues and must remain strongly committed to multilateralism, exercising a leadership and bridge role between the different WTO partners in all negotiations.  This is no time for regrets. The time has come to require all members of the Organization to immediately ratify and implement the Trade Facilitation Agreement and the time has also come to demand that they be involved and committed to concluding a long, too long Doha Round and the roadmap to be followed after the Nairobi Conference.  I don't accept a defeat. To this end, I believe and share with the Commissioner that some partners need to come up with positions to reduce distortions in trade in agricultural products and export subsidies; emerging economies effectively exercise their respective share of responsibility based on their level of development and their involvement in international trade; and that there is greater flexibility of advanced countries in favour of less advanced countries.  Finally, WTO reform is needed: it needs to strengthen its parliamentary dimension and it needs to strengthen its governance so that no doubt about its usefulness and need is admitted.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Of course, it would be nice if the WTO rounds were developed to the point where we no longer need bilateral agreements. We could save ourselves all the controversy over TTIP, CETA, etc. But I would like to point out something else: why are globalisation and free trade so important? We must not forget that globalisation brings not only goods, goods, services and investment around the world, but also ideas and values. It is thanks to globalisation that today we have recognised human rights as a global challenge and an opportunity. Incidentally, we also see that there are more democracies in the world today than ever before. This, too, is a consequence of globalisation. So we must stand up for the WTO, for trade, because trade also leads to more than prosperity. Moreover, ladies and gentlemen – here comes my Ceterum censeo – I believe that the single euro only leads to strife and discord in Europe and must therefore be abolished. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – I would ask Mr. Representative whether, if we take it theoristically, all these bilateral or regional agreements would be reached, whether you think a global agreement could be formed from it. I don't think so, but I want your opinion.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Yes, I would think that if we had an ideal global agreement, we could all save ourselves these bilateral agreements. However, it has to be said that all bilateral agreements have contributed more to world trade overall than the WTO has done so far. Nevertheless, the objective remains clear to me: we must lead the WTO to global success, and then we will no longer need these agreements.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Mr President, Madam Commissioner, Europe needs a world where all doors are open to our businesses, and global free trade is the key to those doors. If we want Europe to be strong, we must support all measures to ensure the removal of barriers both within the WTO framework and outside. Now we must draw a line under the last 14 years of the Doha Development Agenda (DDA) discussion and move forward. I believe we can do this within the WTO, but only if we adopt a new strategy and a new vision for it as an institution. What do we need at this stage to reach this goal? Firstly, we must finish this round in some form, to keep the multilateral agenda moving. I hope that the European Union will continue to be at the forefront, leading this discussion. But there needs to be greater engagement of all members to bring some meaningful results from these talks, even if these are less than we originally hoped for. Secondly, after this is done, in order to recommit ourselves to a multilateral trade agenda, we need a new plan on how to progress within the WTO trade agenda that is not just a repeat of the same old ways. The Nairobi meeting should be about achieving and accepting realistic results on the DDA on the one hand, but it should also aim at charting an ambitious way forward for the WTO more generally. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr President, I totally agree with what our colleague has argued, and I totally agree with what the rapporteurs say, but I would like to ask you, dear colleague, if you do not think that, however, the World Trade Organisation must have a different trade agenda, so that by entering strong countries into the World Trade Organisation , not to come to unfair competition as we have now very often, for example from China, with the entry of uncontrolled products? Shouldn't we review certain World Trade Organisation working documents? Not quotas, but how to control consumer protection.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for your question, and I agree that we are now at a milestone in the WTO negotiations. I think we need the engagement not only of the European Union but of all the members of the WTO, because it is crucial that we move the global trade agenda forward. It is not enough to have bilateral or bi—regional negotiations. I think it is in the interests of all the players to have global trade rules.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: – Mr President, the Doha Round has faced great challenges. The multilateral path is not easy because the interests of rich and poor states stand in contrast and those of the great economic powers are always imposed: those of the North. This makes it impossible to reach consensus that benefits all and especially the most disadvantaged: those in the South.  We must not fall into the supposed pragmatism of the easy path represented by TTE, ACS, AECG or ATP, for these pathways are nothing more than the imposition of the hegemony of the rich through an agreement between giants, between superbs. In Nairobi, it is crucial to redouble efforts to find a democratic framework for trade where all voices are represented; for international trade to become, at once, a tool to overcome inequality, poverty and climate change; and to make it a welfare engine for people and not a tying machine of rights and the environment, which is what these "macro-treatments" entail.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at the Nairobi Conference, what is at stake is the very future of the multilateral system. A system that the European Union and the United States are slowly killing through agreements such as TTIP, the TPP and the TiSA. That is precisely the problem. Plurilateralism is still being insisted on as a solution, but it is not clear that if the multilateral system does not work, it must be reformed, not turned around its rubble.  We must focus on the poorest countries and help them, but we must also abandon the ambiguous distinction between developing and developed countries: such as China and India, for example, which can send a man to the moon, but which call themselves developing countries and take advantage of them accordingly. We must help the poorest to obtain from others the generous concessions that we already offer and we must finally use the WTO to reach agreement on the rule of origin. These rules are better negotiated multilaterally, and that is why we must make every effort to ensure that Nairobi is a success, if we have not already chosen the path of agreements such as TTIP and TiSA, and in this case we have really lost everyone.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would first of all like to congratulate You Bernd Lange and Pablo Zalba on this important resolution, which reflects the European Parliament's priorities for the tenth WTO Ministerial Conference in Kenya in December.  Let us remember that the creation of the WTO represented a fundamental step towards a more integrated and dynamic trading system. The WTO has also meant that developing countries, with economies in transition, and least developed countries can leverage trade to drive their development.  Through the WTO, the European Union has demonstrated its interest in fostering a multilateral framework for trade negotiations that coexists with bilateral, regional and plurilateral agreements.  Our environment is evolving; the international trading system has changed and will continue to do so in the coming years. We are in a more open system, with new countries in transition that are part of a reality to be taken into account.  We must therefore maximise the opportunities emanating from trade, and that is to support a structural reform of the WTO to ensure a more open and fairer trading system that takes into account the interests of SMEs, micro-enterprises and innovative new enterprises.  It would also be important to remove trade barriers in highly innovative sectors, such as renewable energy, and this would give a strong impetus to a sector in strong growth and job creation.

name: David MARTIN
text: – Mr President, as the Commissioner herself has said and other Members have pointed out, we should not miss the symbolism of Nairobi being the first time that a WTO Ministerial Conference has been held in Africa. We should see this as an opportunity to put development firmly back on the Doha Development Round and emphasise, as much as possible, development items during the course of the Ministerial Conference. Firstly, I hope the EU will continue its support for special and differential treatment and put that at the core of some of our debates during the Ministerial Conference, particularly trying to target the least-developed countries (LDCs) to ensure that they benefit from the opening up of trade. As others have said this afternoon, we all welcome the conclusion of the Trade Facilitation Agreement. We should aim to try and get that signed before the Ministerial Conference, and I know the Commissioner is working on that. I do not pretend it is an easy task, but again, the symbolism of getting that done before Nairobi would be vital. We should also (I think it was Mr Rübig who raised the issue) try to push our Member States to deliver on their aid-for-trade commitments. The European Union institutions have largely delivered on the commitments made at Gleneagles a number of years ago; the Member States have almost universally failed to do so. So we need to press them in this regard. Finally, although it is not a matter for the WTO Ministerial Conference, I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Commission for the position it recently took at the WTO TRIPS Council on the extension of IP exemptions for medicines for LDCs. This is a real contribution to ensuring access to medicines for the poorest countries in the world.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, I believe this resolution comes just in time to show the EU’s commitment in advancing the Doha Development Agenda based on free and fair trade for the benefit of all. The proposed provisions support the structural reform of the World Trade Organization. This reform will, hopefully, contribute to a better and more open trade system – a more non-discriminatory trade system – based on shared and applied rules. I believe that change is necessary. I believe that the WTO system must change to be more efficient and better suited to reality – to the real problems – and better suited to fulfil its role in helping SMEs and micro-enterprises and also innovative start-ups. I hope that this resolution will embrace the specific interest of the low-income developing countries and the least-developed countries as well, because it supports the establishing of appropriate definitions of low—income developing countries and emerging economies as well. This will help resolve the recurring problem, for example, with China in the WTO system. Lastly, I believe the provisions of the resolution aim to ensure sustainable economic growth and development by supporting liberalisation through accompanying policies. Taking all this into consideration, I fully support this resolution. I believe that it will suit, and be beneficial for, all the members of the WTO.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, at the next Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organisation, the European Union must confirm its strong commitment to advancing the multilateral agenda. It must call for a rethink of the WTO, which will be able to overcome the difficulties of responding to the challenges of our time.  Europe must make every effort to conclude the important bilateral agreements currently under negotiation. But it must be remembered that the main objective of European trade policy must be to push for the creation of a system of multilateral agreements that are the guiding principle of fairer globalisation.  With the ratification of the agreement on trade facilitation, the European Union is presenting itself with the right papers at the Nairobi Summit. This first wto agreement provides for an innovative tailor-made approach to the least developed and developing countries, which will allow them to choose the timing and methods of implementing the obligations.  I therefore hope that a clear and effective strategy will be established in Nairobi to strengthen multilateral trade.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Free trade is our most important tool for creating prosperity and eradicating poverty. That is why a global trade agreement is so incredibly important. Yet we have spent the last thirteen years hardening with the DOA round and trying to get it to the finish line. This does not make it any less important – that it has taken a long time – that we achieve success in Nairobi. I would just like to point out three reasons that I think are particularly important at the moment with our success in Nairobi. The first is to kick-start the world economy. At the moment, uncertainty in the world economy is significant and the major risks lie on the downside. The second is that right now, more than ever, we need global rules of the game and global tariffs to meet the jumble of different rules of origin and tariffs that all the free trade agreements we have created, which have exploded in recent years. This is the only option when the multilateral negotiations do not go, which somehow corrects it so that trade does not become expensive and complicated, as it risks becoming. The third reason is that the credibility of the WTO is at stake. The credibility of the WTO as an arena in which negotiations are conducted and for free trade friends and not just an arena for dispute resolution. Just because it is important clearly does not mean that we can expect success. I have learned this in my 12 years of following the issue. As the Commissioner himself points out, I do not have enormous hopes that we will finish the round. On the other hand, I hope for one thing – because there are things that can be done – and that is the success of the sectoral negotiations, the plurilaterals that are taking place on the sidelines, such as the issue of a free trade agreement for environmentally friendly products. I believe that the European Union and the Commissioner can make an enormous difference there, and I very much hope that she can come home and present that we are abolishing tariffs on environmentally friendly products, because that is what the environment, Europe and trade need. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: João FERREIRA
text: according to the "blue card" procedure. – Mr President, Mr Fjellner has made another of the usual professions of faith in the free market here. But if free trade for development is so important, how does Mr Felner explain that the majority of developing countries - for example, the ACP countries - have resisted, as long as they have been able, to try to impose free trade agreements on free trade agreements, which are the so-called Economic Partnership Agreements? If it's so good for them, why did they resist while they could? And by the way, give us examples of developed countries that are industrialised countries that have reached this condition without a strong protectionist policy over the years.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: blue-card answer. – If that were true, I might actually agree with you, but the fact is that most ACP countries are on the way to concluding economic partnership agreements with the EU. That is a fact. And we can see that, as a consequence of free trade, we have fewer extremely poor people in the world now than ever before. That is due not to communist ideals of the sort that you promote, but to free trade and nothing else.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I too would like to thank the rapporteurs because this resolution expresses realistically, but also forcefully, the hope that we can finally achieve that decisive drive at global level, in order to face up to the challenges that are being posed and on which concrete solutions must be found. Faced with the uncertainties and changes in our way of thinking about globalisation, which is also globalisation of evil, unfortunately – as we are experiencing with particular pain these days – the Nairobi meeting is becoming even more important, because it could be an opportunity to bring out the positive face of this globalisation. A globalisation in which the multilateral system is strengthened, the aim of which is the sharing of fair and inclusive rules and in which the needs and needs of the least developed countries are taken into account, and in which the focus is certainly on economic development, certainly, but also social, environmental and human development, in the broadest sense. For all these reasons, I very much hope that a renewed and reinvigorated WTO will be the right direction taken in Nairobi: that is our priority, as expressed in the resolution.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for As you pointed out, the WTO Ministerial Conference in December 10 will be held in an African country for the first time. As the 2001 Doha Declaration clearly points to the links between trade and development, it is the interests and needs of developing countries that must continue to be at the heart of every aspect of the negotiations. More than two-thirds of The World Trade Organisation's members are developing countries. Removing trade barriers and tackling new ones is an important tool for sustainable growth and development. Experts estimate that the successful conclusion of the Doha negotiations on this issue will lead to an increase in global GDP of up to $300 billion per year. Most of this growth will fall on developing countries and least developed countries, which in turn will have a positive impact on the material situation of their inhabitants and significantly reduce poverty levels. During the forthcoming negotiating round, the most developed countries should take on a greater share of the responsibility for the solutions implemented, adapting them to the capabilities and specificities of poorer countries. Liberalising trade and increasing market access for these countries will provide greater opportunities for South-South and developed countries to exchange, especially in the key agricultural area. This access should be facilitated by the abolition of quantitative restrictions and customs duties. Every step must be taken to ensure that the opening up of markets translates into real benefits for all people in their daily lives. It is important that the Representatives of the European Union strive for significant progress in the negotiations and for the conclusion of the Doha Development Round.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Malmström has reminded us that there is less than a month to go before the 10th Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organisation, but we must recognise that the preparatory work is far from satisfactory and is a success in Nairobi. And no bilateral or regional agenda replaces an ambitious and balanced multilateral agenda. This is a multilateral meeting, Commissioner. And there is therefore no success possible without building, in this preparatory phase, the right alliances and strong alliances towards a fairer and more sustainable development that uses trade in the right direction. What I ask the Commissioner is what is the European Commission doing and what can it still do to Nairobi to build those right alliances, these strong alliances, for success at this interministerial conference?

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We see that this debate is urgently needed. We are in the middle of the digital age, the world is growing together, and we are still having discussions like the start of the Doha Round. The world has changed dramatically, and I believe that the Aid for Trade area – that we are helping small and medium-sized enterprises, that we are helping the self-employed in those areas where there is abject poverty – should be the most urgent objective.  Corruption must be combated first and foremost, because in many areas tariffs, administration hinder it and prevent trade. I believe that it is also important that we take care that people have enough to eat again. How can we provide the ten billion people who will be living in 2050 with food? So trade facilitation, Aid for Trade and agriculture, this is a package that is urgently needed.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Doha Round and the enormous preparatory work bear witness to the subtle and difficult balance between the opportunity for WTO members to pursue legitimate trade policy objectives and the need to grant the necessary aid to developing countries to meet their own necessary global trade standards. Well, the bridge between these two realities is still very fragile and part of the leading role must be played by the European Union, which must facilitate the Doha Round with the aim of creating new trade opportunities and resolving the current imbalances in the system. We must therefore pursue the protection of multilateral trade rules and not direct direct compression, which comes from bilateral agreements, while at the same time being useful. One way is certainly that of respect, in the current agricultural negotiations, in Article 20, of the Marrakesh agreement on agriculture, which specifies the need to respect the principles of a not immediately commercial nature: environmental protection, food safety, rural development, animal welfare.  The aim is no longer elusive to achieve inclusive and sustainable growth and to reduce commercial costs through transparency and legal certainty.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the Doha Development Agenda must aim at economic growth, establishing rules to facilitate fair trade and reducing imbalances in the international trading system. However, what is ultimately happening in practice is the complete and unconditional liberalisation of trade which leads to deindustrialisation, reduced employment and economic crises.  At the same time, farmers are also being harmed, while the World Trade Organisation has not only been characterised by a deep democratic deficit, but has failed to help prevent the financial crisis.  It is therefore necessary to develop fair and balanced trade regulations that serve social justice. In addition, each State should maintain its sovereignty in the regulation of its economic relations and in the allocation of resources in the various public sectors, in order to prevent speculation by large enterprises through imbalanced trade relations and trade.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, world trade must become an instrument and driver of development. It has to become a mechanism by which those of us who are richer will help the weaker ones, because isn't it better to do something towards relief in world trade than to bring humanitarian aid, isn't it easier for multilateral trade mechanisms to do something for the developing country, to enable their economies and agriculture to move forward and thus give them the hook to catch fish, not to bring them fish because we don't have enough money to give fish to someone forever so they can eat. We need to help feed ourselves, but in a way that they affect world trade and help ourselves and all of us together, because how in just a few years are we going to feed the 10 billion people that are going to be on the planet?

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, you are well known that The success of Bali and the success of the WTO will only be at the expense of the most disadvantaged and weakest people on the planet: the peasantry and the popular classes. Because, despite how much some and some of you have said here, the reality is that the more international trade, the more free trade, the poorer there are in the world, and the more wealth is concentrated in a few hands. And let me remind you that at the 2003 Ministerial Conference in Cancun, Mr. Lee Kyung Hae, a peasant whom the World Trade Organization prevented a dignified life, took his own life at the gates of this Conference to denounce the tragedy of the disappearance of the world's peasant economies. This is no time to move forward with the WTO, it is time to put an end to it. You also speak in the motion for a Resolution that CAP reform meets the expectations of the WTO. The destruction of the way of life of thousands of peasants in the European Union shows that the WTO is a failure for Europe and for the world.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this debate, and thank you also to the two rapporteurs, Mr Zalba and Mr Lange, for the work that you have been doing. Even though there are some dissenting voices, there seems to be a great deal of support for your resolution, so congratulations on that. Like most of you, the Commission and myself are very committed to the multilateral system. We need to do everything we can to vitalise the WTO because, yes, we do need an international forum in which we can split up international rules and to which almost all the countries of the world now belong: 161 and growing. There are so many issues that we need to discuss at global level, so we need to free energy for that in the future. But first, of course, we need to deliver in Nairobi. The process is called the Doha Development Round, so we should not forget development: that is the reason for all the efforts made by the Commission so far. And yes, Mr Pereira, we have been working very hard to ally ourselves with other countries – like-minded ACP countries that have met many times – in an attempt to see how we can push forward a joint agenda. We need to make sure that the poorest and most vulnerable countries in the world become the beneficiaries of this agreement. And that is why we are looking at export competition. We have tabled proposals to address agricultural export subsidies because they are indeed very damaging to the poor world. We are looking at different development-related issues such as duty-free quotas, free rules of origin, cotton, services, etc. And we are also looking at increasing the transparency of the system. This is not easy. There are many different voices in there, so we are working very hard in Geneva. And I would like to say, for the benefit of the colleagues from UKIP (who have now all left), that when 28 countries speak unanimously with one voice, as we do in the WTO, then of course we have quite a lot of leverage. But that is not enough; there are 161 countries, so we need to move forward. It is possible to have different views on how far we have reformed the CAP, but it is true that we, the European Union, are the world’s biggest importer of food from the world’s poorest countries. We do not use export subsidies for our food today, and that is why we are pushing for their abolition in Nairobi, together with Brazil and many others. We are working hard. There are three more weeks. We need to make sure that there is an outcome, but it is not certain yet. We will do whatever we can until the very last moment in Nairobi to achieve an agreement on the way forward. And yes, Mr. Fjellner, I hope that we can also include trade facilitation and push for aid for trade and green goods if that is possible. We are also making progress on the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA), but that would have a parallel track  rather than being dealt with in Nairobi. And I will be looking forward to regularly meeting the delegation from the European Parliament, who I know will be in Nairobi. Hopefully, when we next discuss this after Christmas, we can at least be happy that some conclusions were reached there. If all this fails, it will not be because of the European Union.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: I have received a motion for a resolution to conclude this debate. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 26 November 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. – The 10th WTO Ministerial Conference will be held in Nairobi in just under four weeks. The priority of this conference is to adopt a clear and detailed work programme for the conclusion of the Doha Development Agenda. This objective is unlikely to be achieved, as the negotiating lines between developed and developing countries are far apart on important issues. It concerns the agricultural sector, where developing countries are demanding better market access, the reduction of import quotas and tariffs and the reduction of subsidies by industrialised countries, as well as market access for non-agricultural products, which comprise 90 percent of the world's trade, from mineral resources, raw materials for further processing such as.B oil to forestry and fisheries, as well as supply and access to services. , e.B. non-discrimination against third countries in public procurement. As a result of the summit, the European Union expects a comprehensive work programme, which provides for liberalisation measures in the field of non-agricultural products and services, as well as export competition in the agricultural sector, as well as tariff reductions for agricultural and industrial products without exceptions for developing countries. The US would be content with a minimal version. The major agricultural exporting countries are demanding substantial improvements in market access, and emerging economies such as India are insisting on maintaining derogations in opening up their agricultural markets.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on human rights in EU-Vietnam trade negotiations by Bernd Lange and Marietje Schaake on behalf of the Committee on International Trade (O—000116/2015 – B8-1106/2015)(2015/2821(RSP)).

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Author. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done Next week, on 2 December, the Prime Minister of Vietnam will come to Brussels and sign the trade agreement. I think this is a very good agreement that has been negotiated between Vietnam and the European Union. It has a very clear but asymmetric tariff reduction roadmap, standards have been agreed, 169 GIs have been accepted by Vietnam – 169 GIs – and other partner countries should take an example. Public procurement has been agreed and a level playing field has basically been created. In this respect, it is truly a remarkable agreement. And this agreement, too, made a clear reference in the preamble to the 1945 United Nations Charter and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights of 1948. In other words, the trade agreement has a clear link to the issue of human rights and the safeguarding of human rights. There is therefore no question that the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, which was launched in 2012, has a legally binding link with the trade agreement and is therefore also relevant to the trade agreement with the human rights clause from the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement. I believe, ladies and gentlemen, that we all agree that human rights and trade are, of course, directly linked. I cannot imagine a trade relationship where human rights are not respected. Incidentally, in the TPP agreement, which Vietnam has also signed, progress in human rights development has been explicitly linked to market opening, in other words, an automatic system has been developed. Human rights are therefore part of trade. If you look at Vietnam now, we all know that Vietnam is a very dynamic country, is in a process of transformation and presents challenges and many issues of human rights must also be addressed, in particular, for example, the issue of freedom of expression. The human rights dialogue must, of course, be seen as an instrument, within the framework of the clause in the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement and in connection with the trade agreement. And there's a bit of the bunny in the pepper. The question of how to improve this human rights dialogue, so that it may be a little more active. Perhaps on five points, the question of whether we need improvements, that is to say the question of the definition of objectives for the human rights dialogue, we need concrete milestones in the talks. Sometimes, I feel like the conversations are a bit simmering. Secondly, how can it be better to involve civil society in the dialogue? We have the Civil Society Forum, we have Domestic Advisory Groups. I believe that the trade agreement will also develop into independent trade unions, we can guarantee clear rules of involvement and also material support, where civil society does not have the means to do so. Thirdly, we can improve the coherence of the EU, both at Commission and EADS level, but also at the various levels of negotiations and discussions, that there is real coherence in EU policy. Fourthly, what about the evaluation of the human rights dialogue? Is it possible to draw in even better benchmarks and indicators? Fifthly, transparency – this is a favourite issue for us – and that transparency can certainly be strengthened in the human rights dialogue. So, some questions about how to strengthen this human rights dialogue, especially in relation to Vietnam, but in view of the trade strategy, of course, for further agreements.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission is, as you know, committed to promoting and protecting human rights in all our engagement with third partners, including, of course, with Vietnam, which we are discussing tonight. With this aim, we organised a Stakeholders’ Consultation in May, and the summary paper of the discussion published thereafter highlights the stakeholders’ suggestions for improving the situation of human rights issues and underlines our commitment to transparency and to regular and continued engagement with civil society. I can confirm that issues relating to human rights have been addressed in the context of the EU-Vietnam Free Trade Agreement negotiations, with the aim of embedding respect for human rights in the agreement, and also with a view to enhancing its positive impact and minimising the risk of adverse impacts. I have also personally discussed matters with the Minister. The preamble of the agreement reaffirms the EU’s and Vietnam’s commitment to key international human rights principles and instruments. There is also an institutional and legal link between the Free Trade Agreement and the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Vietnam. These links ensure that respect for human rights underpins EU-Vietnam bilateral relations, including the FTA, and enable us to take measures considered appropriate in the event of a breach of the agreement. The FTA also contains provisions ensuring the transparency and inclusiveness of the decision-making process and any legal proceedings, thereby strengthening the enabling environment for the respect of human rights, democracy and the rule of law in Vietnam. With regard to labour rights, the FTA includes an ambitious chapter on trade and sustainable development, and that includes not only respect for all core labour standards and ratification of fundamental ILO Conventions and their implementation, but it also pays special attention to corporate social responsibility and fair and ethical trade schemes. The monitoring of human rights development in Vietnam is, of course, very important. This will continue to be done primarily through the institutions and structures set up in the PCA framework, including the human rights dialogue – and there will be a meeting in a couple of weeks again. We also have a dedicated instrument, the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights, as you all know. The implementation of the commitments undertaken will be followed up in both the EU and Vietnam through the mechanisms and institutions established therein, as well as through the existing EU civil society dialogue and with ex-post evaluations of the FTA. I strongly believe – and I think Mr Lange said the same – that trade liberalisation and human rights can and must go hand in hand. The new Communication on trade and investment that the Commission published a couple of weeks ago makes it clear that EU trade policy must be for all: citizens; consumers; workers; the self-employed; small, big and medium-sized companies; and the poorest people in the developing countries. It must deliver growth, jobs and innovation, but it has to be responsible, and that means that EU trade policy must defend European values. It has to be effective at delivering economic opportunities and it has to be transparent and open to public scrutiny. Human rights are therefore a very important part of this trade strategy. The Commission wants to ensure that trade policy contributes to the advancement of human rights in the EU and in third countries, in conjunction with our other policies – foreign policy and development cooperation. Let me assure you of the importance of finding this balance between engagement and conditionality. The Commission is, as you know, convinced that the policy of engagement is more effective than a policy exclusively based on conditionality, even if that can also play a role. Engagement allows us to engage and to create channels for dialogue, keeping them open with a lot of stakeholders involved. We intend to make full use of those channels to promote change on the ground in Vietnam. Thank you very much for your contribution to this, and you can be sure that we will keep you informed very closely about the development once the agreement is finally concluded.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, three years after the signing of the Global Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation between the European Union and Vietnam in 2012, an understanding of the Free Trade Agreement was reached last August, by the way, with a communist country. For the European Union, this Agreement has great economic relevance, as it is expected to increase and facilitate market access with a GDP growth forecast of 6% in 2015 and will also create new investment opportunities.  The Free Trade Agreement has a binding relationship with the Global Framework Agreement on Partnership and Cooperation, which includes human rights clauses. This link ensures that these principles must govern relations between the European Union and Vietnam, also covering trade relations.  Twenty-five years have passed since the establishment of diplomatic relations and, in this period, we have seen a progressive improvement in the human rights situation in Vietnam. It is true that there are still deficiencies; in particular, the death penalty continues to apply and there are harassment of civil society activists, media restrictions and limitations on religious freedom. We must condemn these practices and push for their rapid eradication, but we must not forget that Vietnam is taking steps in the right direction.  Vietnam is currently a member of the United Nations Human Rights Council and in 2014 ratified the Convention against Torture and the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. We must continue to monitor the human rights situation in Vietnam without forgetting that the European Union's so-called best friend at ASEAN remains a promising ally for the European Union in Asia.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the trade agreement between the European Union and Vietnam, which will be closed on 2 December, is of fundamental importance for a number of reasons. The negotiations are particularly important, not only for trade relations between the two countries, but also more generally, for the relationship between the European Union and ASEAN and for the Community's trade policy. It is a strategic agreement for these reasons but also, as President Lange has already said, for the content and quality of the negotiations.  For this reason, it can be a model for future agreements, and it is precisely for this reason that it is essential to monitor, very carefully, all aspects of them, including those relating to the chapter on sustainable development, which is becoming increasingly important also in the light of the European Commission's trade strategy. It is precisely for this reason that we have put this question to the Commission. , during the implementation phase and for new impact assessment models, with greater involvement of civil society in the negotiations. We are convinced that trade agreements are even more effective if they are a useful tool, including to improve the social situation of their counterparts. That is why we believe that agreements cannot be concluded which do not take this dimension into account.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Vietnam is a dynamic, young country, 90 million amiable inhabitants and, above all, a country that does not wait for work, but creates work. I have seen this time and again in Vietnam. We have a communist government, a communist party, which not only wants socialism, but also wants to increase national prosperity through state intervention. Certainly, and we know this, people can speak freely and act freely as long as they do not disturb the authorities.  Now human rights come into play: I think it is wrong to always work on the normative track when it comes to human rights. We should take a different approach, and that is an analytical approach. In a world of globalisation, if you want to get out of imitation and create something yourself, you need people who can think. Reflection, negotiation can only be done if there are human rights. It should be made clear to the Vietnamese that it is important, for an analytical reason, that they achieve human rights in their own interests.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Madam Commissioner, the ALDE Group welcomes the fact that this trade agreement and trade negotiations, which are the first of their kind between the EU and a developing country, Vietnam, have been concluded. We think it is a good agreement. Trade, as an element of the broader EU foreign policy agenda, is one of the more concrete instruments and one where Parliament plays a leading and important role. But we should also think of development policies. We see, too, that citizens are increasingly and actively getting involved with this discussion, and we welcome this. People in Europe are very clear that they want to see human rights at the top of the European foreign policy agenda. I believe that human rights are key. I think that the EU has both the opportunity and the responsibility to lead in ensuring that universal human rights are respected worldwide. While trade must be an important lever, it cannot in and of itself be the solution to end all suffering and problems. Listening to the public debates, people sometimes have very high hopes of the impact that trade can have. But realistically, we must do what we can. I see this ambition and vision – tying trade and values – clearly reflected in the Commission’s new Trade for All agenda.
