Besides the anticipated boost to development and economic well-being, building on Vietnam’s efforts to lift people out of poverty, I would like to know what short-term measures are anticipated. How does the Commission address human rights in the context of trade and how does monitoring look after the agreement enters into force? There is a lot that has to be improved in Vietnam. Free expression, free association, freedom of assembly are all controlled and under pressure; torture and beatings unfortunately happen too regularly; and minorities, journalists, bloggers and opposition figures suffer as a result of this. In conclusion, these many challenges cannot be solved through trade alone. We need to work and build on the human rights dialogue and show political leadership. I look forward to continuing this discussion and monitoring the impact this trade agreement will have on human rights in Vietnam. I will continue to address it in other ways as well.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the Commission has reached a principle of agreement on a free trade agreement with Vietnam and this surprises us deeply, because the suggestions of this Parliament, nor the recommendations of the European Ombudsman himself, have not been followed at all. An agreement has been reached without even carrying out an impact assessment on human rights in line with the Recommendation of the United Nations, which both the Ombudsman and this House called for. It is true that the Agreement includes the traditional chapter on sustainable development, but we all know that it is insufficient. They are nothing but beautiful words without effective marks for their fulfillment. What ensures that the parties fulfil their obligations? Nothing. We also consider it essential that attention be paid to the potential impact that the Agreement will have on gender issues. It is essential that the European Union's trade policy does not go against our gender equality objectives. It is also crucial that the issue of corporate responsibility for human rights violations and social and environmental standards be addressed. We cannot continue to allow the total impunity of large corporations to the detriment of the rights of the people and the planet. Without these elements, the agreement with Vietnam will be a new failure of European politics, with dramatic consequences, as always, for people.

name: Ska KELLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Protecting human rights is at the heart of the European Union and the European project and should also be at the heart of European trade policy. In Vietnam, human rights are not looking good at the time. Vietnam is at the back of the table when it comes to freedom of the press. Non-governmental organisations are banned, as are political parties or trade unions. The Commission has just presented its new trade strategy, which puts human rights at the forefront in an exemplary manner. But it is also a question of how we implement this in our trade policy in a very concrete way.  We still have a lot of catching up to do with Vietnam, because we do not have an impact assessment, for example, on the impact of the trade agreement on human rights on the ground in Vietnam. As Greens, we would have to register some question marks, especially when it comes to the application of investor protection. We have not seen such human rights requirements in this agreement. That is why it is very important that we look specifically at what we can improve with trade in Vietnam when it comes to human rights. We have good words on this so far, but these words must also be followed by deeds.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the human rights situation in Vietnam is appalling.  Power is firmly managed by a single party that suppresses all individual and collective freedoms. Freedom of association, assembly and expression are all systematically violated; torture is widespread and the government uses forced labour for the production of goods for export.  And what does Europe do? He decides to reward this champion of democracy by signing us a free trade agreement. An agreement that could be used as a means of exerting pressure to achieve real democratic reforms and defend the rights of Vietnamese citizens.  On the other hand, we find ourselves once again making agreements with dictators, in addition, using European agriculture as a bargaining chip: our farmers will see 80 000 tonnes of Vietnamese rice enter our market duty-free, as is already the case with Cambodian and Myanmar rice under the EBA. Is this value-based trade policy? No, Commissioner, I do not think so.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for In August, the EU-Vietnam Free Trade Agreement was completed after three years of intensive negotiations. It is an important and good agreement for Vietnam. After all, the EU is Vietnam's second largest trading partner after China. This agreement is indeed an agreement for growth in a country that needs development. I firmly believe that trade is the best way to get out of poverty. This is how Sweden and all the other EU countries became rich. If we can offer other countries the opportunity to make the same trip by opening our markets, that is of course a good thing. But as always when poverty reduction comes up in the context of free trade, opponents say that it is exactly the opposite. That trade threatens human rights, workers and the environment and that free trade takes place at the expense of the population. That's not true! Let me just say that the Vietnamese themselves want this agreement. I think, frankly, that it is a bit pathetic when you try to claim that you know better than they themselves know what is good just for Vietnam. In addition, this agreement contains strong, binding wordings on human rights, the environment and workers' rights. I don't think that's where the shoe squeezes. The truth is that protectionists always find another excuse than being protectionists, to try to obstruct free trade and open borders. I think this is another example. As we saw when it came to Burma, when Aung San Suu Kyi appealed to us to reduce their tariffs, they were opposed. As for Pakistan and Malala stood here and pleaded, they were against. Now we are opposed to Vietnam, because you think you know better than the poor what is right for them. These are the imperialists of the new age.

name: David MARTIN
text: – Madam President, firstly, I agree with Bernd Lange that this is a very good agreement in economic terms for the European Union and for Vietnam and it should see growth in both regions. Is the human rights situation in Vietnam perfect? No – as other speakers have said, far from it. Whether this free trade agreement will help or hinder the human rights situation in Vietnam is probably the more important question, and I happen to agree with the Commissioner that constructive engagement is the way to improve the human rights situation in Vietnam. Thanks to this EFTA, we will now have an opportunity for a robust ongoing human rights dialogue with the Vietnamese. I hope we will also see a very effective domestic advisory group set up. That, to my mind, is a crucial point: we have to make sure that we fund a domestic adviser group, involve civil society in Vietnam and get regular reports about the situation there, particularly the labour situation. We must make sure that the ILO conventions are being implemented, that trade unions are allowed to operate, and that there are safeguards at the workplace. But we cannot do that if we do not have this FTA or the PCA. If we are not engaged with Vietnam, we will have no basis on which to speak with the Vietnamese. So I repeat: good for economics and also potentially good for human rights in Vietnam.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Madam President, respect for human rights develops; it does not just happen because a country ratifies international agreements or they are bombarded with demands from potential trade partners. Human rights evolve, and fostering trade is a vital part of enabling that evolution. ASEAN is the EU’s third largest trading partner and Vietnam is growing in importance within ASEAN, with a vibrant economy. So I welcome this agreement, which I believe will lift people out of poverty in Vietnam and enable them to engage vigorously in improving their own political and human rights in their own country in good time. I look at human rights sites monitoring Vietnam and of course I am dismayed at what I see sometimes. But hectoring and then withdrawing is not the answer. I am pleased to see this agreement finalised. Let us engage constructively continuing our dialogue, provide governance assistance and get on with seeing this FTA become successful. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – I would like to ask our colleague, Ms Girling, what would happen if a policy combining engagement and strong, tough conditionality had to be embedded by the European Union in the strategy for relations with all developing countries, including Vietnam.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Regrettably I did not really understand the beginning of the question, so it is difficult for me to reply.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Let me try again. The question was: a policy of both engagement and strong, tough conditionality should have to be embedded by the European Union in the strategies of relationships with developing countries, including Vietnam. Do you understand now?

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Sorry, Madam President, I still do not understand that English.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I am going to ask you perhaps to speak to each after the session and try to reach an understanding.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: – Madam President, during my visit to Hanoi this month I saw a capital with a lively growing economy and remarkable results in achieving many of the Millennium Development Goals, but I also learned about the absence of free trade unions and increased pressure on human rights activists, and that the country ranks 175 out of 180 countries in the 2015 Press Freedom Index. The changes that come with more trade and with free trade agreements do not automatically lead to a society without economic inequalities, without human rights violations and with strong labour rights. Therefore, I welcomed very much that the Commission already in 2012 committed itself to systematically carrying out human rights impact assessments for free trade agreements, which it expressed in the EU Action Plan for Human Rights and Democracy. In April 2014, this Parliament urged the Commission to carry out as soon as possible a human rights impact assessment. Despite several reminders, open letters and so on, and even strong criticism from the EU Ombudsperson that the fact of not doing so would amount to maladministration, the Commission refused to follow this recommendation. The main reason recently given was the lack of time and the fact that the Commission does not want to delay the conclusion of the free trade agreement. But the Commission committed to including a human rights impact assessment in the next ex—post evaluation. UN experts this summer voiced clear concerns over the adverse impact of free trade and investment agreements on human rights and also called for ex—ante and ex—post human rights impact assessments. I do not think that any explanation of sustainability criteria in the EU Free Trade Agreement with Vietnam will be sufficient. The Commission should do nothing less than a thorough human rights impact assessment.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I have listened to some of the speeches and I have to say that I do not at all agree with the happiness with which this free trade agreement with Vietnam is welcomed.  I believe that when we talk about this House's love of neoliberalism, we put beautiful slices of ham on our eyes, even in the face of human rights violations, which are very serious in the case of Vietnam, because we are talking about a country that is in 175th place for freedom of the press, where new political parties cannot be founded. , where there can be no free trade unions, where non-governmental associations and organisations are prohibited, where the government uses so-called hooligans to repress human rights defenders. And when we say that through a free trade agreement we want to improve these conditions, we are mistaken, because an agreement that gave priority to human rights had already been concluded in 2012, a partnership and cooperation agreement, with the result that human rights violations have worsened over time. That is why I would say that we really should turn the page when we talk about such agreements.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, I would like to raise the following serious issue in plenary. I've put it before. The plenary meets so that we can participate in the debates. This week in Strasbourg is devoted to plenary. We cannot have committee meetings at the same time, in particular meetings and votes in committees. At this time, at 7 o'clock in the afternoon, I am invited to take part in a vote at a joint meeting of the LIBE and PETI committees on a serious matter which is FRONTEX.  I am protesting because I want to take part in the debate. The committee programme cannot therefore deprive us of the right to participate in plenary. I would ask you to pass this matter on to The President. Schultz and to point out to the chairmen of the committees that this week is plenary week and not votes in committees. The votes in the committees, next week in Brussels.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: We take note of your comments and we will pass them on to Mr Schulz. Now we continue with our debate.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, I would first like to welcome the conclusion of the free trade agreement with Vietnam, which is an important partner of the European Union in the context of Southeast Asia. This is the first new generation trade agreement with a developing country and can therefore be a model for future agreements with ASEAN countries. But trade is not an end in itself, and the Union's own trade and investment strategy underlines the need for trade agreements to promote European values and, in particular, human rights.  Now, we have good reason to be concerned about respect for human rights in Vietnam, in particular freedom of expression. And this House insisted that the European Commission apply an approach based on the conditionality of its trade agreements.  I would therefore like to ask the Commissioner what progress has been made in Vietnam on human rights since the beginning of trade negotiations and what lessons should we learn from this process - whether we can consider, whether the Commission can consider that this agreement with Vietnam has effectively respected the principle of human rights conditionality on a trade agenda?

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, let me say that, as standing rapporteur for the EUROPEAN UNION-Vietnam Free Trade Agreement Committee, I did not support asking this oral question and including or provoking this debate. However, I find myself in a minority on the committee, and I respect that, of course. I believe that the issue of human rights was given great attention during the negotiations on this trade agreement, that the commitments described there are also sufficient and that Vietnam will respect them. And it's also our job to oversee the implementation of the agreement. And I believe that we must now concentrate on the final stage of ratification of the agreement. I am very happy that her symbolic signature will take place next week. Last but not least, let me stress that I am also glad that we have managed to establish a group of friends here in the European Parliament, the European Union-Vietnam, in which all the Parliamentary groups are represented, which is indeed an exception, and I believe that this group will help the smooth ratification of this agreement.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, I welcome this FTA. It has important potential in terms of jobs and growth, not least for the EU in the current context of TPP, but also for Vietnam. But it is clear that this potential can only be realised if appropriate measures are taken to maximise positive, and prevent negative, impacts on human rights. Vietnam does face significant challenges in this field, whether it is forced evictions of farmers or imprisonment of those seeking better labour rights. Therefore, could the Commission explain why it is not possible to undertake a proper ex-ante human rights impact assessment so we can understand a roadmap for addressing our concerns and improving the solution? It is also evident that the usual mix of instruments will not do the trick. Not only do they have their shortcomings, which have been widely documented; but can we really just blindly transpose this approach onto the most far-reaching FTA that has ever been achieved with a developing country? Some argue that the Commission’s timid approach to human rights is exactly why it is important that under the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement there is a communication mechanism between the European External Action Service (EEAS) and Parliament on the implementation of the PCA and capacity—building to enhance the settlement of complaints by the affected communities. This is not about trying to undermine the FTA or pointing the finger at the Vietnamese Government. This is about common sense – that prevention is more effective and less expensive than cure – and about casting a successful foundation for a strong, lasting, strategic relationship with one of our key partners in south-east Asia, especially in the current geopolitical context.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Human rights are a process and a basis for people to live human rights, that – first – they are not hungry, that they have work, that they can be educated and that they are ultimately the ones who demand human rights. Such a trade agreement will give and give dignity to the people of Vietnam to work, and I am sure that in this process we will also come to greater human rights demands. Those who too quickly expect that in some state system that is left behind, where hungry and poor people are, that human rights will start to be implemented at a high level, they should remember how we are from this city and from many other people elsewhere for human rights, asking and asking for people in Iraq, Libya and Syria, but today we ask ourselves how these people have human rights fulfilled. They don't even have the right to live. Human rights are a process, and I therefore support this process, because it will lead to greater human rights in Vietnam.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, after two and a half years of intensive negotiations, the European Union and Vietnam have reached an agreement in principle for the signing of the Free Trade Treaty. The agreement will make it possible to increase trade with one of Asia's most dynamic economies, an agreement that could be useful, therefore, for both economies.  However, there remain many strong concerns about human rights violations in the country. Twenty-four independent organizations, mostly vietnamese civil society, some international, have prepared and disseminated a report that draws attention to the human rights violations that took place in Vietnam in 2014. The document includes abuses of freedom of religion or belief.  The Treaty will contain a binding clause under which it can be suspended in cases of serious human rights violations. The Commission must monitor respect for human rights in the country and demand compliance with the commitments made in the agreement, so as to lead to an effective and not just stated improvement in human rights in Vietnam.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the Free Trade Agreement signed in August 2015 between the European Union and Vietnam eliminates customs duties on trade in goods, services and investment and projects growth in the European Union's GDP of more than 2%. In the context of the negotiations between them, the European Union and Vietnam are supposed to have launched a structured dialogue on the protection of human rights, which must also be the basis of any trade agreement, in accordance with the Treaty on European Union.  However, this agreement does not give a damn about the human rights violations that are taking place today in Vietnam and does like the other trade agreements, TITT and TISA, which are only interested in profiting from large multinational enterprises at the expense of small and medium-sized enterprises and thus lead to a reduction in employment in the countries in which they are implemented.  That is why we must promote agreements which do not harm employment and workers and respect human rights.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, I am amazed by the arguments of some of our colleagues in this room today when they say that this agreement should not be signed, because human rights in Vietnam are not respected. We mostly know that human rights are not respected in Vietnam, but the same female colleagues often use the argument that we should not export our form of democracy, Western democracy, respect for human rights to other countries and we do not need to impose anything on others.  I see this agreement, Dear Madam Commissioner, first and foremost as the EU's desire to fight poverty in Vietnam, as it is one of the most impoverished countries on the globe. That is why I support this agreement, aware of the fact that the topic of human rights, today and probably tomorrow, will be a distant topic in this same Vietnam, but the fight against poverty is one of the EU's obligations. In this context, you also have my support.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, the European Union is still based on the values of ensuring and respecting human rights, and we must also enforce this principle in its various forms of cooperation with third countries. At the same time, we cannot be blind idealists who say that we will not cooperate with certain countries or regions until their human rights regime reaches the level that prevails in the EU. We must also add that, in many cases, we do not set a good example ourselves as far as human rights, notably minority rights, are concerned. The institutions of the European Union are as powerless in influencing the relevant policies of the Member States as they are in third countries. Moreover, the Commission seems to be more cautious in criticising member states' practices than by resithing third countries. I don't think that in any way strengthens our credibility in the world.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I absolutely agree on the need to make sure that human rights-related issues have been correctly addressed by the Commission during the negotiations with Vietnam on a free trade agreement. Considering the concerns about the human rights situation in Vietnam – particularly with regard to freedom of expression, the right of assembly, the right of association, media freedom, the right to disagree, freedom of religion, etc. – I believe that the Commission should monitor human rights developments in Vietnam and draw on input from independent civil society in order to uphold the commitments made in the agreement. I support the negotiations, as trade agreements have demonstrated the potential for economic growth and jobs on both sides. However, it is fundamental that the Commission address the relationship between trade liberalisation and improving human rights in trade negotiations in the future, including in the new trade strategy that it plans to put forward.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: – The Free Trade Agreement with Vietnam, which builds on the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, could have been such a reading example of how the European Union can demand the promotion of human rights from its new trading partner, as we see them in Europe. I think it is very important that we look at the rights of people with disabilities there. That people are not free to gather at all. That there are no independent trade unions. That Saigon, which was once a multicultural example of a country where many religions were also represented, today freedom of religion is still trampled on in this communist country. The Commission should be far more consistent in enforcing this trade document and give partners the kind of access to human rights that we would like.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, of course, trade alone cannot solve all of the world’s human rights problems, but it can make a contribution by enhancing respect for human rights and fostering sustainable development. That is what we are committed to doing in our agreements, especially the one that we are discussing tonight – the agreement with Vietnam. Nobody denies that there are severe problems relating to human rights in Vietnam. You have listed many of them, and I could add a few more. They are there and they are serious. That is why we need to address them and why we are engaging with the Vietnamese authorities. There have been some improvements – far from enough – but the Vietnamese authorities seem to be willing to engage with us. That is why we have developed tools for doing this. We have the legal link between the FDA and the partnership agreement. We will make evaluations, especially looking at the human rights situation. We do have the human rights dialogue that the EEAS is conducting. There will be another meeting in a couple of weeks, and we will set up advisory groups with civil society in order to monitor this on the ground with people who are there and are familiar with the daily situation. To explain all this, we will by the end of this year – in a couple of weeks – publish an ad hoc Commission paper explaining how the existing measures of the partnership agreement and the negotiated measures of the free trade agreement will contribute to human rights empowerment with the flanking measures that we will put in place and how the human rights I mentioned will be assessed once the latter agreement has entered into force. All this will, of course, be public and transparent so that you can follow and contribute to the dialogue. There is a conditionality clause in all of our agreements to cover very serious breaches, but we prefer whenever possible to work on engagement and to try to establish forums for dialogue to see if we can make improvements. If we have no agreement with Vietnam, we will, of course, say no to all such forums. I am not sure whether that would contribute to empowering the people of Vietnam. This agreement will be finally concluded next week. Very shortly after that it will be published so that you can read it and make your own assessment. Then, during the whole translation and legal procedure, there will be plenty of time for discussion, and the Commission is ready to enter into that dialogue with you. I can assure you once again that we will keep you informed at all stages and are always ready to take your input, ideas and views into account and to have a dialogue with you on this.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the accession of Ecuador to the EU-Peru and Colombia trade agreement (2015/2656(RSP)).

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, we welcome the resolution by Parliament on the EU-Peru and Colombia trade agreement and the accession of Ecuador. The accession of Ecuador has been agreed between the EU and its Member States and Peru and Colombia and is another step forward in our effort to engage with Latin America and consolidate our position in the region. That is important for us. The Commission considers that this agreement will be beneficial for both sides. It will enable us to consolidate traditional trade flows while also boosting and diversifying trade and investment on both sides. We also hope that it will act as an economic driver for social development in Ecuador and contribute to alleviating poverty and reducing inequalities. They are there, of course, in that country. The text of the accession protocol results in a comprehensive and balanced agreement, fully matching the ambition reflected in what was concluded with Colombia and Peru. It also takes into account the differences in economic development that obviously exist between the EU and Ecuador by allowing Ecuador longer periods for dismantling tariffs and making some specific adjustments that it has requested. The accession is of paramount importance for Ecuador because, as of the end of next year, Ecuador will lose its preferences as regards access to the EU market. Timely accession will not only ensure preferential access for Ecuadorian products to our market but also bring long-term stability and predictable conditions for bilateral trade and investment. And we will, as we discussed in the last item and as expressed in our trade strategy, pay special attention in order to make sure that the provisions on trade and sustainable development are implemented and used effectively, including by offering appropriate support through development cooperation. Ecuador, as you point out in your resolution, has shown its willingness to engage in an area of trade and sustainable development and agreed to sign up to all the provisions of the trade and sustainable development chapter. This will help us to identify a common agenda in which we can cooperate and exchange best practice. As is the case with other agreements, cooperation with you and with Member States and the input of civil society will be crucial for effective implementation, in particular of the sustainable development chapter. And to get it right, we really need your engagement and your input, and this resolution reflects your commitment. We have taken due note of your request to be regularly informed about trends in banana imports, including those from Ecuador, once the agreement is in place. I can assure you that close monitoring of banana imports and developments in the market situation has once again been proving effective so far. The resolution is a vital step in Ecuador’s accession process, but it is not, of course, the end of our conversation. We will continue the process leading to implementation of the agreement. The Commission will continue to take your views carefully into account and continue the dialogue that we have here. So thank you again for the excellent work on the resolution. I am looking forward to the debate and, as always, we are fully committed to cooperating with you on this agreement until and after its entry into force.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, in July last year the negotiations for Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement between the European Union and Colombia and Peru were successfully concluded. It is good news, which will be very positive for both sides, but we must not forget that it was Ecuador that requested to rejoin the negotiations it had abandoned in 2009. Today we are here discussing this proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament which, together with the adoption of the Agreement itself and the Regulation on the Safeguard Clause, will complete Ecuador's accession procedure.  I would like to thank Mr Scholz for the work he has done and for the good cooperation we have had throughout the process. The PPE Group tabled some amendments to the motion for a resolution which we voted on in the Committee on International Trade, which were intended to enrich the text and give the Clear Support of the European Parliament to Ecuador's accession to the Agreement. I am pleased that the final text reflects this. This Agreement will boost trade and investment on both sides, enhance economic and social development and help reduce inequalities. We cannot forget that Ecuador is no longer a beneficiary of the GSP+ system, so ratification of the Agreement will bring significant benefits for Ecuador's exports to the European Union.  Finally, I would like to recall that, in its resolution of 13 June 2012, the European Parliament, before giving its approval to the Agreement with Colombia and Peru, asked the Andean countries to establish a roadmap on human, environmental and labour rights. I think it is important to remember this as our group's position is to treat all the countries that make up the Agreement equally.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done In fact, we welcome Ecuador's accession to the agreement, because we originally wanted an Andean agreement, because integration at regional level is, of course, also an important central momentum of our policy towards the countries of Latin America. I also think that we have cooperated well with the resolution – with Mr Scholz, Mr Fisas Axelo and the other parties involved. Thank you very much for that. I think the direction is also true: we want to organise accession, but we also want to improve implementation. Hence the reference to the roadmap that we have launched with Colombia and Peru – by the way, with Mr David and myself, as the traders who negotiated this roadmap to the governments, because indeed, Commissioner – you are absolutely right here – not only the negotiations are crucial, but the implementations are decisive and gradual in the implementation of the project. , also on the issue of workers' rights, environmental standards, to work together to find a way forward in order to achieve improvements.  In this respect, Ecuador is certainly also called upon to go in the same direction as Colombia and Peru, also in order to make progress in this area, particularly as regards the question of labour inspectors, because the ILO Convention of 1929 has not yet been signed. So here we – the Commission and Parliament – will have to show joint commitment to ensure implementation.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to express our full agreement with Ecuador's accession to the Trade Agreement with the European Union which Colombia and Peru have enjoyed since 2013. I regret that two years have been lost and I hope that accession will have the same benefits for Ecuador as those provided so far by this Agreement to its signatories. In Colombia alone, it has particularly benefited four million working families who have seen their exports grow by 21%. The Union is already Ecuador's main recipient of exports. In 2014 sales of our market reached 2.4 billion euros, with a surplus of 400 euros. Some scholars believe that 300,000 jobs offered by 1,400 companies, almost all SMEs, are directly linked to this trade flow and that the Agreement can improve short-term exchange by another 400 million. This policy of trade concertation has proven to be a first-rate tool to contribute to peace, stability and progress in the area. It provides growth, development and environmental and social guarantees. It produces social justice in an area of the strategic planet for Europe because of its situation, its potential, its size and its growth rates. A significant number of new Europeans or residents who arrived in Europe come from these countries. The negotiations further underline that very diverse political options value and endorse such agreements, which offer palpable, counting and sounding advantages to thousands of families and workers, who see opportunities born or consolidate their professional or business expectations. I hope that this will encourage Bolivia to join this alliance, which will be more powerful if it integrates the entire Andean Community. In short, it is a European contribution in terms of peace, justice and development to global trade. That is why, Commissioner, our group will be at your side to carry out future projects.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done The Government of Ecuador has decided to accede to the EU Free Trade Agreement with Colombia and Peru. It has thus also given in to the economic constraints imposed by the EU's competing neighbours on EU trade and the simultaneous cancellation of the GSP-plus benefits for Ecuador. In fact, Ecuador had proposed its own agreement on trade and development, also in order to be able to continue the remarkable development path for a social lyrical and environmentally conscious country in the Andean region, also in partnership with the EU. We all know that the European Parliament's approval of the agreement with Colombia and Peru has long been uncertain, even controversial. It was finally carried out on the condition that concrete steps be taken to improve the human rights situation, the social situation and the environment in the region. These are objectives for which the Government of Ecuador has been particularly successful in recent years. That is why we should take a close look. Ecuador's accession to this agreement is an important moment for the country itself, but also to check whether the provisions of the general agreement with the Andean countries and their implementation are in line with our expectations, both socially and economically. The first figures presented to us by the Commission on the development of trade with the other two Andean countries fall far short of initial expectations. And in this respect, once again, we must also look closely at the implementation of the agreement and stick to it. With this draft resolution, as rapporteur, I am, above all, following our responsibility as the European Parliament to show the European Commission where we see a need for action to make the agreement more effective, so that it still serves the people of both regions. In this sense, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for a resolution that is close to these objectives.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Ecuador's accession to the European Union Agreement with Colombia and Peru certainly opens up great opportunities for all parties, but the benefits will only be possible if we work fairly and fully comply with all the conditions set out.  Coming from the Canary Islands, the largest banana producer in the European Union, I would like to focus today on the need for this agreement not to become another threat to the already weakened banana sector of the European Union, which looks with concern at how an uncontrolled entry of bananas from Ecuador can now occur. Let us not forget that Ecuador is the largest exporter of bananas to the European Union and it is clear that exports are growing proportionately to lower tariffs.  Let us remember that in Geneva we adopt a declining rate of up to EUR 114/tonne; bilateral agreements reached up to EUR 75/tonne by 2020. We assume this as inevitable, but it is precisely for this reason that two issues must be addressed: the first, compensation to Union producers who may be harmed; and the second, the need to implement the safeguard clause with complete diligence in the event of excesses in the agreed amounts which may cause harm to Union producers.  Madam President, I vote 'yes' to trade agreements; "yes" vote for Ecuador to join the current Agreement; "yes" vote to the development of this country. But not at any price, not at the expense of banana producers in the Canary Islands and the rest of the European Union.  I'm not asking for any favors, I'm just asking for the agreed agreement to be fulfilled. There is a safeguard clause, the limits must be respected and, if not met, the agreed mechanism must be put in place, and it should be done automatically when they are exceeded. That is what we vote on mostly in this House and that is what must be fulfilled. Ecuador does not have to have better differential treatment than Colombia and Peru can have, and the Commissioner has said this: there is a safeguard clause that needs to be put into force and not look the other way.  I believe, Commissioner, that we cannot look the other way while many families living on bananas in the Canary Islands and other outermost regions of the European Union see the future in fear.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I share with you that Latin America is a very important partner from a commercial point of view for the European Union, especially in view of the view that other major economic operators — China, for example - are occupying a very important position there. I believe that for the Andean Community Ecuador is a very important country, and I also believe that for the political environment of the ALBA countries Ecuador and its President Correa are particularly important. I believe that we have a political need and a commercial need to make this agreement and I add to the voices that claim it. Ecuador was probably wrong when it decided not to join the multi-party agreement with Colombia and Peru. But we are now strongly and clearly expressing its political will to join the Agreement and it also brings us a commercial economic anguish, because it needs, before the end of next year, this Agreement for the future of its exports. I believe that Europe has to take this step. There are no reasons for human rights, sustainable trade, to prevent this Agreement. It is a serious country, it is an economically important country, politically influential, and I believe that Europe has to take this step. I am grateful that the Commission is consting this negotiation and that it is working with Colombia and Peru to avoid vetoes of this Agreement.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, thank you very much to the author of the motion for a resolution for his open attitude to dialogue and consensus and for his excellent work. I would also like to highlight the commitment and firm and determined support of the Spanish socialist delegation to the commitment of the European Union's political relations with Ecuador, and we certainly congratulate and congratulate the Commission on the work done, which allows Ecuador to join the Agreement with Peru and Colombia. And we also believe that it is important that this agreement, as Mr Jáuregui said before, enters into force within the time limit necessary for Ecuador to take full advantage. But this afternoon we had the opportunity to see how fundamental democracy and human rights are to the European Union's trade policy in trade policies and that is why we are defending a chapter of sustainable development with very clear conditions on labour rights, freedom of association, the fight against child labour, the defence of gender equality , protection of indigenous peoples and increased protection of the environment. We are confident that this will be the case and that we will do the best to follow up on the Agreement on behalf of the citizens.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Ecuador's accession to the agreement signed in 2012 between the European Union, Colombia and Peru is a further step in improving trade relations with Latin America. Pending the formal end of the ratification process, Quito's participation in the free trade agreement broadens the geographical scope of this important, state-of-the-art treaty on the protection of social labour and environmental standards. It is precisely for this reason that we hope that the Government will implement the action plan to improve the conditions of its citizens as soon as possible. Through this decision, Ecuador is also continuing the virtuous path of special relations with the European Union, in continuity with the previous inclusion in the heart of the generalised system of preferences.  Latin America is historically and culturally a strategic area for the European Union. We hope that Ecuador will be a stage on a path that sees, in the near future, the implementation of a balanced and ambitious agreement, including with the Mercosur area.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: – I welcome Ecuador's accession to the trade agreement that the European Union already has with Peru and Colombia. I think it is a step in the right direction, and it is something that will benefit both the European Union and this Latin American country. I have been more involved recently as Vice-President of Eurolat on the issue of cooperation between the European Union and Central and South America, and I like the fact that Ecuador is such a true tangible example of such progress. Diversifying partners is both beneficial for Europe and for our employment. Of course, we must also not forget the human rights dimension and social development in this Latin American country.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, Ecuador has dared in modern times to proceed courageously in writing off the country's external debt to third parties, and this is an important signal in all directions.  Today we are discussing Ecuador's accession to the European Union's trade agreement with Peru and Colombia. However, in order for the Ecuador agreement to be beneficial, provision must be made for the liberalisation of trade to be in favour of the People of Ecuador and not of the multinationals. This means that provision must be made for the protection of small and medium-sized enterprises, local employment, labour rights and the rural economy, and this cannot be done by trade agreements which promote a complete and unconditional liberalisation of trade in goods and services.  A safety net is therefore needed for vulnerable social groups and for the poor and financial mechanisms to offset the social impact of opening up the Ecuadorian market to European Union businesses.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, this agreement we expect with Ecuador and its accession to our overall agreement with Peru and Colombia shows the importance the EU is devoting to andean countries. That is why it was well said today that we need to see, enable and expand cooperation with other Andean countries and have such treaties because this is certainly an indicator of our interest in these countries.  On the other hand, this decision is a confirmation of the importance and role the EU plays on the global global market. That is why I am sure that with this treaty we can help peasants in Ecuador, those who are engaged in agriculture, but at the same time we should take into account the fact that we could harm some of our farmers, especially those who produce bananas in the Canaries, and therefore we must be careful and have the right to protect our production.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, as many Members have expressed, we have a joint interest in deepening the cooperation between the European Union and Colombia, Peru and Ecuador. The agreement with Peru and Colombia is a good agreement, as has been said, and we are convinced that it will also be good for Ecuador. Of course there are special mechanisms for Ecuador, bearing in mind the differences in the economy, but it will be good for them in enabling them to develop their economy and also in addressing the social issues. It will also be good for the regional integration of these countries with each other. We will, of course, monitor this very closely once it has entered into force, together with the EEAS, looking at the situation of human rights, labour rights and sustainable development, as with all other issues. The second report for Peru and Colombia is being finalised. It will be sent to Parliament very soon. On bananas: I have heard the concerns of some Members expressed here. We have, as you know, a stabilisation mechanism. We are looking at this very closely. We will continue to observe this with a very attentive eye, keeping you informed. Of course, Ecuador will also have this safeguard mechanism; we will be amending it to make sure that Ecuador is also covered by it, and we will continue to look at it and regularly report to Parliament so that you can reassure your constituents. So thank you very much for your general support. I will be looking forward to a positive and strong support for the resolution tomorrow in Parliament. We have read it very carefully and will, of course, study the possible amendments and so on, and I think it will be very helpful for us in concluding this work.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I have received one motion for a resolution from the Committee on International Trade tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 26 November 2015.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on a new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020 by Czesław Adam Siekierski on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (O—000141/2015 – B8-1107/2015) (2015/2957(RSP)).

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: Author. – The Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development presents a question on the new animal welfare policy for the period 2016-2020. Content of the question: The European Commission Communication 2012(0006) on the 2012-2015 Animal Protection and Welfare Strategy has been welcomed by the European Parliament and provides a clear roadmap for action in the field of Union animal welfare policy in recent years. The European Parliament was particularly pleased that the strategy introduces many aspects of Parliament's resolution 2009/2202 – own-initiative report of 5 May 2010. Parliament appreciates the progress made so far and encourages the Commission to make sure that the outstanding elements of the action are implemented in time.  So, firstly, will the Commission draw up a new animal protection and welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020 to ensure the continuity and clarity of the actions that are crucial to achieving further positive changes in animal welfare policy in the European Union? Secondly, will the Commission prepare, as a key element of the new animal welfare policy, a proposal to simplify the framework for Union legislation on animal welfare, which Parliament calls for in its resolution on the Union strategy for the protection of animal welfare for the period 2012-2015, resolution 2012/2043 , also an own-initiative report. That is the question of the European Parliament's Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, and now my reference to the problem. The subject matter which is the subject of the question is systematically raised in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, in various forms and scopes, when working on many documents and on other occasions. Animal welfare has an important place in our awareness and values that are important to humans. It is also part of sustainable development.  This issue occupies a special place in the European Union, where we have done so much to improve animal welfare. The standards and requirements we have adopted are very high and we respect them, even though they are causing a significant deterioration in the competitiveness of our animal products on world markets. The reports discussed earlier today also address these issues. We should ensure that our standards in this area become global standards, which is very difficult. And such requirements should be placed on imported products from third countries.  We are currently dealing with key animal issues to varying degrees, in many areas, in many reports. I will mention only the titles of the documents that we have been working on or have been working on recently. These are 'Zootechnical and genealogical conditions relating to trade in breeding animals and their biological material used for reproduction and their importation into the Union'; 'Cloning of animals of the bovine, ovine and ovine species and horses kept and reared for rearing purposes'. The next topic – 'Animal health', the next one – 'Veterinary medicinal products or Community procedures for the authorisation and supervision of medicinal products for human and veterinary use and the setting up of the European Medicines Agency', finally 'Trade in seal products' and many, many others, which I do not mention here.  Problems of linking and affecting animal welfare on the quality of food products and thus on human health are extremely important. A number of discussions raise problems of hormones, antibiotics in the food and treatment of animals or the use of animals in scientific research, the results of which often ultimately contribute to improving animal welfare, despite previous doubts and reservations about the advisability of their use and scope. To sum up, I would like to say that animal welfare is and will remain an important value for us.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, animal welfare is an important and sensitive issue very close to the hearts of millions of European Union citizens. I, too, share the concern of many Europeans for the proper treatment of animals. The current European Union strategy for animal welfare adopted by the Commission in 2012 is still in progress. The priority of the Commission is therefore to work on completion of the remaining actions. Furthermore, there is work to be done on the strengthening and enforcement of existing rules, on improving dialogue with stakeholders and on exploring ways to better include animal welfare considerations in our international activities. On enforcement: the European Union has at its disposal a very extensive set of rules for animal welfare, covering many species, including broilers, laying hens and pigs; many activities, such as transport, slaughter and animal testing; and also products, for example, cat and dog food or seal products. We need to prioritise the critical issue of putting the existing rules into practice. Learning from our experience over recent years, we must focus our efforts on tackling widespread non-compliance. Against this background, I intend to work on improving compliance with a requirement to prohibit the routine tail docking of pigs and on the finalisation and adoption of guidelines on the welfare of pigs, as foreseen by the animal welfare strategy. Secondly, I look forward to the outcomes of the ambitious pilot project on best practices on animal transport, supported by Parliament. The project runs from 2015 to 2018. Thirdly, I would like to mention the Commission proposal to revise European Union legislation on official controls, which has the potential to improve enforcement of animal welfare requirements, for example, through our proposals to establish European reference centres for animal welfare. On stakeholder dialogue: I would like to see this dialogue amongst the wide variety of actors concerned with animal welfare developed further. I intend to promote, or first attempt to see if there is an appetite in the Community for, this kind of exercise. On the basis of the outcome, we could decide how to structure this dialogue for the future. Finally, on international action: clearly the concern of European Union citizens as regards the treatment of animals does not stop at our borders, and rightly so. We need to continue promoting our approach worldwide, also to protect the competitiveness of our livestock industry, which has made so many efforts on these issues in recent years. Such efforts can help us to keep European Union standards at a high level, despite the pressure that globalisation brings. I will explore, together with my colleagues responsible for trade and agriculture, how the potential market of animal welfare could be better valorised at global level. European Union animal production must seek to profit from its advantageous position as a world leader on animal welfare to steer this trend and to further explore markets demanding ethical production. Since the animal welfare strategy is about to end, we are evaluating further steps. In this case I would like to inform you that the Commission will launch, in 2016, a new Eurobarometer Survey on animal welfare which will represent a useful source of information, especially in the areas of consumer awareness and education. We will be ready to evaluate our next steps after the Eurobarometer Survey has been analysed.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development has repeatedly expressed its sensitivity to animal welfare, which fortunately has the highest level of protection in the world in Europe. The 2012-2015 strategy is now coming to an end and we are here to ask the Commission for its intentions on a possible new animal welfare strategy. However, before asking for new rules, I would like to know whether and what actions of the current strategy have not yet been implemented and whether there is still work to be done for full and uniform implementation of the current strategy. I would also like to add that, at a time when we are calling for increasingly stringent rules for our farmers, without raising the problem of reciprocity, we risk penalising our production system and at the same time relocating certain farms outside Europe, thus substantially worsening the welfare of many animals.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, as with all European policymaking, I believe our animal welfare policy should be led by science, evidence and practical realities of farming and food production, not driven by emotion and public opinion, no matter how well-meaning it may be. The way to create the best outcomes for the welfare of animals is to have a sensible and workable strategy that is not implemented in a burdensome way for producers. We need to recognise the practical implications that exist for producers and be wary of unintended consequences which can ultimately have a negative impact on animal welfare. For example, the Commission’s proposals regarding medicated feed could potentially have implications for pig welfare by delaying the use of medication until the disease has spread and developed. The cost to farmers – or ultimately, of course, to consumers – must be recognised. Producers where I come from in the UK, as a whole, were to the forefront in implementing measures such as the sow stall ban, while others dragged their feet. The United Kingdom banned sow stalls and certainly lost their competitive advantage at that time. Similarly, there is a need for our animal welfare standards to be protected in any trade negotiations. We cannot allow a situation, for example, where imports from third countries have a competitive advantage over those produced within a Europe under our high animal welfare standards. Bovine TB is a problem which impacts on the welfare of cattle, and the associated restrictions place pressure on farmers and come at a cost to the public purse. The truth is, if Member States were to implement the regulations that are in place much better, there would be much better animal welfare.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: On the other: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I shall begin by saying that I am very pleased that this issue has come so far. If any colleagues recognise the wording of the Committee on Agriculture, it is because it is the same issue that many of you signed just before the summer and which we have finally had up for debate. I am particularly pleased that the House is today deciding to bring a resolution to this written question and this debate. I would also like to thank Commissioner Andriukaitis for your commitment to the issues and for opening up some ways forward during your introductory speech that we will be able to discuss in the future. I would like to agree with the colleagues who have spoken before that we first need to make a proper evaluation of what we have had in the previous strategy. Next, I would like us to be able to ask for a new strategy for the future. Because, as Mr Nicholson said, it is extremely necessary that we take it in a package, that we have it balanced and that we also get it – which I think is extremely important – in a work that is done with Europe's farmers and not that it becomes a work that is against Europe's farmers. It's the core. I would also like to see that in that strategy, which gives us a broader perspective and a wider range of different instruments to work on, we also have a part that is to work towards common animal welfare legislation within the European Union. Many times in the political debate, it is said that we have a common agricultural market in the European Union, and we have that to a large extent. But there is also a great deal of national regulation that differs. We can see how many different directives have been implemented in very different ways in the different countries. If we take what is popularly known in Sweden as the Pig Directive, for example, where we got ten years of implementation process from 2003 to 2013, we can see in a survey from the Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences that only eight out of twenty-eight countries have fully implemented this. We have also previously been able to merge the link between how much antibiotics we use in our livestock production with how it also affects our health as humans. Here we have an opportunity to actually get more of Europe, better rules. Some 30 pieces of legislation that have passed this House are certainly not so coherent. Here we have the chance to make it better and easier and to have a better and functioning internal market, while at the same time keeping animals in Europe much better off.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. The suffering we do to animals is enormous and a new animal welfare strategy will enable Europe to do something about it. The basis for this has already been laid in Article 13 of the Treaty of Lisbon, which states that animals are beings of awareness and feeling, which we must take full account of.  But what are these words worth if the Commission does not show any initiative in the field of animal welfare and leaves animals to their fate and to market forces? What are these words worth if Europe offers protection from cruel bullfights or even the burning of bulls? What are those words worth if the unsedated slaughter of animals is still allowed, when there are alternatives? And what are those words worth if the endless towing of animals in overcrowded cattle cars through and out of Europe is still allowed? What are these words worth if we do not ban the painful coercive feeding of animals for the production of foie gras?  Mr President, the Commission can tackle these abuses, not with a Eurobarometer study but simply with a new animal welfare strategy. But last week she informed several NGOs that it had no intention of coming up with a new strategy, and that was before this debate with Parliament had taken place. That cannot be true, Mr President! I hope that the Commission will today show respect for the broad appeal from society and Parliament to stand up for animals. They are entitled to it. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Albert DESS
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I have to apologise, but I have realised what open borders are worth, and today the border from Germany to France was dense. I was at the border for more than two hours. On the part of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I welcome the request that the Commission draw up a new animal welfare strategy for the coming period. We all know, especially as farmers, that animal welfare is a top priority. Only healthy animals, only animals that are kept well, also perform. We all want not only the animals to be kept well in agriculture, but also the pets. We should also include this in the new animal welfare strategy. However, I would like to point out one thing: we must not exaggerate the whole thing. If it leads to production being moved from Europe to other parts of the world, then we are sinning against animal welfare. Between 1976 and 2008, animal production and meat production in Europe increased by only 6% and in Asia by 385%. In other words, if we gag our farmers too much, we will be relocated to parts of the world where our animal welfare rules do not apply. I would therefore ask that we do this with a sense of proportion, that we keep an eye on the welfare of animals, but that we carry out it in such a way that production is maintained with us and that small farms in particular are not endangered. Strict rules mean that small-scale farms in particular are the first to close their farms. I can only take one example: if we really bring about the ban on cows, many small mountain farmers in the Alpine region will close their farms. I therefore ask that we find something sensible. I am very confident about that.

name: Keith TAYLOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, this resolution of the Animal Welfare Intergroup, of which I am a vice-chair, is both timely and welcome, and my Group wholeheartedly supports its objectives. Particularly welcome is the checklist on the existing strategy, where it is noted that only nine out of 19 actions that were called for have so far been implemented by the Commission. That is why any new strategy should urgently and loudly call for a comprehensive and clear animal welfare legislative framework law which improves animal welfare standards and does not dilute them. It is a concern of ours that when some people talk of simplification of rules, it is a dilution. What we need is better implementation. There are too many elements of the proposed resolution to talk about in the time allowed, but special mention should be made of calls to embed the sentient status of all animals; the EU—wide ban on mistreatment and suffering of animals; to study the animal health dairy cattle standards against our own and correct any differences found; and finally, to review the transport of animals and the regulations and how they are implemented. Animal welfare issues are regularly in the top three subjects in my constituents’ e-mail bag. Citizens care about animals and are looking for their Parliament to protect them.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, when we are talking about animal welfare in Europe we have got a real clash of cultures, haven’t we? Because in Mediterranean countries they still find it fun to watch bulls fighting one another and bulls being baited. Now, you could say: when in Rome, do as the Romans do, and I might take that attitude. Unfortunately, because of the way the CAP works, British taxpayers are subsidising this activity. They are subsidising it because they are paying area aid on land that is being used to rear bulls for bullfighting and bull-baiting. I realise that this has been in the legislation – there have been amendments about it – but as yet, as far as I know, there has been no concrete legislation that says British taxpayers’ money must not be used for this – not that I suppose that would ever happen. But I should just warn you that there is a referendum coming up in Britain fairly soon on EU membership, and there is nothing that makes Europhiles squirm more than being reminded that they, with their taxes, are supporting bull-baiting and bullfighting. Now we move on to another subject, and that is wild stray dogs in Romania, which are apparently being shot and killed one way or another. That is an animal welfare issue, but I am more concerned about what happens to these dogs once they have been killed in whatever ways they are being killed. Are they buried? Well that would upset the EU because of the environmental rules about burying dead animals. Are they being incinerated? Well that will upset all you global warmers because of the CO2 that is going into the atmosphere. Are they being rendered down with abattoir waste to be spread as meat and bonemeal fertilizer, or are they actually being put into animal rations as a protein element? I mean, I would not put this past anybody, because it goes on in south-east Asia. But these dogs carry rabies; we understand about 20% of them have got rabies. That is zoonotic – that means human beings can get it, and those human beings could come to Britain because the borders are open. So, what better reason to close the borders than rabies?

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, as the 2012-2015 Animal Welfare Strategy comes to an end, I welcome the fact that this issue is on the agenda and I hope that we will establish a new strategy for the period 2016-2020. If Article 13 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union tells us that the Union and the Member States take full account of the requirements for animal welfare as sensitive beings, we must go further in animal defence and remove all the ambiguities that remain in our animal welfare strategies. Thus, in agriculture, the proliferation of intensive livestock in France and Europe combined with the threat of TTIP makes me fear not only for animal welfare and the environment, but also for human health. I condemned, for example, farms such as the 1,200 bulls farm in Alsace, the 1,000 cows in the Somme, the 1,000 calves in the Creuse or the industrial piggery in Poiroux, in vendée. Another important point is animal experimentation. I regret that the citizens' initiative on vivisection has not been followed by the Commission. I also believe that it is necessary, in view of the current means of science, but also of the inconclusive results of experimentation on animals, that it be permanently banned and gradually replaced by alternative methods.  I would also like to draw attention to the appalling suffering of animals put to death without pre-stunning before slaughter. It is essential, first of all, to make detailed labelling on meat slaughtering methods mandatory. The same is true for furs. Then it is mandatory to stunning animals before killing or slaughtering and to remove exemptions as part of ritual slaughter. On the other hand, special care should be taken to better combat all trafficking in animal species and products such as ivory. The perpetrators of these acts will have to be punished more severely with sanctions that really no longer make them want to reoffend. Finally, I believe it is necessary to ensure that Member States follow existing best practices for the effective and humane management of stray dogs and feral cats.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I too would like to warmly welcome this debate on a possible European strategy for animal welfare after 2015, because, like many previous speakers before me, I consider it very important that animal welfare does not end at border crossings and that, especially here in Europe, a harmonised approach is needed here, for the benefit of animals, but also, above all, for the welfare and protection of producers. My own country, Austria, has truly exemplary standards in many areas of animal husbandry in Europe, for example in the implementation of the cagekeeping of laying hens, but also in the field of animal transport. While our domestic livestock farmers are strictly controlled, there are still some Member States in Europe that have not implemented the EU requirements, especially on laying hens. Animal transport is also often even more competitive.  I too would like to join the previous speakers, who have already pointed out that we are not contributing anything to animal welfare if we simply no longer make animal production possible in Europe. This also applies above all to third countries if, in the area of trade policy, we do not take account of the standards at which animal products are imported into Europe. Very often, EU money is also used here to build stables outside the European Union, for example, with less animal welfare. These products are then imported cheaper into Europe. This is partly insanity that can no longer be surpassed! I would really like to appeal to all those who are committed to even more animal welfare and even more requirements: please do not leave it to pure actionism, also inform consumers that this entails increased production costs. I therefore really hope for your support in the consistent implementation of the labelling requirement for food, because I believe that we owe it to consumers and, above all, to producers in Europe.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Madam President! Commissioner! We are happy to talk about animal welfare and much here in the European Union, but action is being done. I believe we have an obligation to ensure that our animals can live good, safe and painless lives. Our laws must ensure this, and our animal welfare strategy must promote this. Nevertheless, we see every day that animal welfare legislation is being violated in the EU by the Member States. This is the case, for example, in Denmark, where up to 99% of piglets have their tails cut off due to poor animal welfare.  Commissioner, I am tired of waiting! I therefore ask straight out of the bag: when will proceedings be brought against those countries that systematically violate EU animal welfare law? When will the Commission propose an eight-hour maximum transport for live animals, as more than a million citizens in Europe have called for? Finally, what is the point of an animal welfare strategy if the Commission is not ready to take action and take legal action when animal welfare laws are violated?

name: Janusz WOJCIECHOWSKI
text: – Madam President, during today’s voting of the agenda, one of our colleagues said that we have a problem with terrorists in Europe and so it is not a good time to adopt a resolution about the animal welfare strategy. Fighting against terrorism or animal protection: this is an absolutely false alternative. Animal welfare is a European value; it is a part of European heritage. We can be proud of having one of the highest – maybe the highest – animal welfare standards in the world. The majority of European citizens want to continue the process of improving animal welfare standards. The majority of European citizens understand the significance of animal welfare and animal protection for our humanity in the 21st century. The lack of a new animal welfare strategy for 2016-2020 is treated as a very bad signal that the European Union does not want to continue the policy of the improvement of animal welfare standards. It is a very bad signal for public opinion. This is the reason that we call on the European Union to continue animal welfare policy and to prepare the new animal welfare strategy. Mahatma Gandhi said that the greatness of a nation and its moral progress can be judged on how its animals are treated. By adopting the new animal welfare strategy, we can give good evidence of our humanity and our moral progress in the European Union.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, when we talk about animal welfare policy, we need to start by having these animals feel their feelings, feel pain or happiness, almost everything we do. From this we must start when we talk about animal welfare and then we can only understand all that we do to these animals when we breed them, unfortunately clone them, transport them the way we should not, and all that ultimately happens when breeding animals, transporting them and unfortunately, often cloning. What I want to emphasize is certainly the fact that we need a new strategy that should also take into account our attitude towards wildlife, such as the use of wild animals in circuses, for example, trade in a way that is not appropriate.  It should also take into account the fact that domestic animals, especially dogs and cats, are often not treated appropriately and should, when we talk about asylums for these animals, take into account their welfare. This year highlights the strategy the Commission once offered and we now need a new strategy by 2020 that we are eagerly awaiting on our table.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Madam President, Commissioner Andriukaitis, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work he has In the Treaty of Lisbon, the EU committed itself to taking into account the needs of animal welfare as sentient beings. But the animals suffer extremely in mass animal husbandry, long-distance transport and in slaughterhouses. They suffer in animal experiments and hundreds of thousands of stray animals are killed every year in Europe. Compliance with existing rules is under-checked and infringements are not prosecuted enough. There is not even a rearing regulation for fattening rabbit farms. I wonder: where is the will of the European Commission to make a difference in this situation? The animal welfare strategy, which expires this year, has been completely inadequate, as almost half of all the points formulated there are still open. We must, for example, get out of cage systems and announce the fight against mutilation in animal husbandry. In the field of animal testing, we must make it compulsory to adopt already validated testing methods, and we must also press for compliance with our animal welfare standards in trade agreements. I call on the Commission to promote an ambitious animal welfare strategy. A postponement is simply unacceptable! The citizens of Europe do not want to wait any longer! When I think of animals, all I can say is: I can't stand the pain anymore. To the Commission: please, please, do not become a desk offender when it comes to animals and animal cruelty! Show moral greatness now! Act now! That is what the citizens of Europe expect of you. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Albert DESS
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Eck, I have a question for you: how do you explain to yourself that where your former party friends ruled in Germany, the largest mass enterprises were created? In the west of Germany there was a farming. In eastern Germany, where the Communists have ruled for 45 years, mass enterprises have been created there. I would like an explanation from you as to how this was possible.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – Capital always goes where it has the easiest ways to spread. In eastern Germany, this possibility was given.
