But please remember where the investors came from: a lot of them, for example, from Holland. So you have to see that. It has nothing to do with this party. It has nothing to do with our subject today, where we are talking about an animal welfare strategy.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the 2012-2015 strategy ends on a very mixed record and it seems that your Commission is not proposing, for the period 2016-2020, new measures, a new strategy, and you are talking about organising a major survey. It would be totally incomprehensible - at a time when your Commission is negotiating the transatlantic treaty and we are therefore going to talk about the conditions of intensive breeding observed across the Atlantic - that we are not legislating on this essential issue.  The concentrationary universe, in which animals are locked up in unbearable conditions of captivity, should not be tolerated in Europe; these methods, which are imported and which are now being implemented in France, must be banned.  So I ask you, Commissioner, and citizens are entitled to ask, do we defend the major industrial players and agri-food groups, or do we want to protect animals and human health?

name: Marco ZULLO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Article 13 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, as we have already mentioned, states that the approach to animal welfare must be done with respect and protection for sentient beings. Unfortunately, we very often disregard this approach, for reasons of hypocrisy, from my point of view, and for too many exceptions.  We are hypocrites for scientific reasons, when we subject thousands of animals to practically useless testing – science itself tells us so. We are hypocrites for cultural reasons: I am referring, for example, to animals in circuses and to the suffering we cause them with lives that are totally unnatural. We are hypocrites for religious reasons: for example, with slaughter practices with which, here too, we cause them atrocious and completely unnecessary suffering.  So, Mr President, Commissioner, I hope that the new strategy, which is necessary, will put animal welfare as sentient beings at the centre of its action.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the health of each of us depends to the greatest extent on the health of the animals we consume. This is closely linked to animal welfare clearly generated by growing and feeding conditions. That is why we welcome and appreciate the efforts made by the Commission in these directions in recent years, once again stressing the need for them to continue with even greater intensity. The Commission and the responsible structures in the field must ensure that there is a continuous communication that takes into account the needs of consumers and the needs of farmers. A balance must necessarily be struck between the interests of the two entities so that each of them is guaranteed that their rights are respected. I also appreciate that there must be a concern at Commission level not only with regard to the adoption of coherent, simplified and effective legislation at European Union level in this area, but it is imperative to follow closely its implementation in the Member States where, unfortunately, serious shortcomings are experiencing in this respect. There are unfortunately, unfortunately, major imbalances in the food chain that clearly disadvantage farmers, which can be a limiting factor in investment in this area. Producers are overwhelmed by administrative obligations and the ongoing attempt to simplify them should not make it further difficult for the sector. We therefore believe that farmers who have assumed responsibilities in this area must be guaranteed stability and predictability with regard to investment, as well as a guarantee of fair competition at international level. Member States must therefore make more effective use of the support opportunities offered by the European Rural Development Funds to promote applied research and invest in innovative and modern animal welfare solutions so that Citizens of the European Union benefit from quality and affordable food for everyone.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: – L-annimali huma ħlejjaq li bħalna jħossu, bħalna jweġġgħu u bħalna jsofru. Insibha diffi大li biex nifhem kif persuni jaslu biex jabbużaw min kreatura li i tistax tiddefendi lilha nnifisha. Issa, sfortunatament, ħafna nies jemmnu li l-annimali għandhom jintużaw biss għal skopijiet ta' qligħ ta' flus, għall-ikel, għax-xjenza, għall-kaħ大大a, u modi oħra ta' sfruttament. L-annimali m'għandhomx jiġu abbużati u għandhom jiġu ttrattati b'dinjità u rispett. L-annimali la għandhom vu大i u lanqas għandhom vot biex jipprotestaw il-mod kif il-bniedem jittrattahom. Għalhekk għandna l-obbligu li nitkellmu u niddefendu lil dawk li m'għandhomxikei. Hekk kif l-istrateġija preżenti dwar il-welfare tal-annimali ser tiġi fi tmiemha din is-sena, inħeġġeġ lill-Gumsjoni biex timplimenta, mingħajr dewmien, il-punti pendenti mill-istrateġija attwali kif ukoll tfassal strateġija ġdida li tkun ta' benefi大大ju mhux biss għall-annimali, iżda wkoll għal kull min iħobb u jirrispetta l-annimali. Ejja nuru kemm aħna verament ħivili billi nagħtu l-vuħi u protezzjoni lil dawn il-ħlejjaq - li ħafna drabi huma ħniena u jafu jħobbu ħafna aktar mill-bniedem.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Madam President, more enforcement in coordination of the regulations that we already have is key to improving the welfare of animals. We know how important the health of livestock is to the success of European farming. It is vital for animal welfare that we continue to support European meat production and do not promote what I call ʽanimal welfare leakage’ by putting our own farmers out of business and ending up with more imports. This does not mean, of course, that there should be no control. Mistreatment of animals must be prevented and care standards must be maintained, and indeed improved. Issues such as transportation are, of course, best dealt with at a European level, as trucks move across borders in the single market – notwithstanding Mr Deß’s experience today. But many issues can be dealt with at Member State level. Many Members here have suggested that there is a lot of talk about animal welfare and little action. That is simply not the case. We have the highest standards in the world. Let us stop talking ourselves down. We just need to make sure that Member State governments enforce them.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Madam President, to ensure a real new animal welfare strategy, we should include in it the fundamental idea which lies behind the protection and welfare of animals. This idea is a philosophical and ethical principle which we usually do not mention, namely this: we have to protect animals because they have rights. Certainly, according to the necessary correlation between right and duties, the fact that we feel obliged to protect animals implies that we recognise the right to be protected and that they have rights. This should be explicitly included in our document, since it is the basis on which we construct our protection and welfare strategy.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: – We are talking about the continuation of the animal welfare strategy. I'm against that and for the following reason. The directives and regulations must be implemented, and we have these instruments in this Parliament. Several ministers have often said during the debate in the Netherlands that this must be done from Europe. Many farmers in the Netherlands have already implemented these directives and regulations.  Now we have an uneven playing field, high costs for the farmer and the citizen does not pay. Practice shows this, and we in this House recently discussed the crisis in agriculture. Therefore, continuation in this Parliament often means tougher demands for farmers, and I really cannot go along with that at the moment. We are now talking about animal welfare. But it should really be about human welfare. In Europe, we let refugees walk in the cold for hours - i.m. elderly and small children - while animals have heating, ventilation and drinking during transport. And we are talking about a reduction in driving time from eight to seven hours. In the Netherlands, the cabinet says that if there is no place for refugees, people should sleep outside in the cold, in the snow. In the case of animals, heating, penal area and light are subject to heavy requirements and this has already been met. Do we in this House not have anything else to do? A resolution on Paris by the EPP was not supported. Let's get to work on today's agenda item. Let us help the people and find solutions to the real crisis in Europe, which is asylum policy, good reception and joint action against the terror group ISIS. That is why human welfare should now be higher on the agenda than animal welfare, which I have always stood firm in support of. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Peter JAHR
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her  I think that our colleague, Mrs Schreijer-Pierik, has correctly described the situation from the farmers' point of view. I am increasingly concerned with the question: should we in the European Parliament not also deal with the animal welfare of pets, because there is little set and little control there? I mean, animals also suffer in the domestic and pet areas. Would that not be an issue for the European Parliament?

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: "blue card" answer. – A totally well-known point. We have said this many times in parliament in the Netherlands. But the same citizens who sit with 10 dogs or cats on a flat eight high say that my pigs do not have a good place and are not well cared for. That is why I believe that you should involve all sectors and all animal issues.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we are finalating the second strategy on animal welfare, which concludes at the end of this year. It's the second strategy we've come through. We have a broad regulation that has meant a different application. It was said in the objectives of this strategy — the outcome of which I am very interested to know — that it was necessary to address the problems in a more comprehensive way, with a more comprehensive harmonization of a common framework on animal welfare. That was the expected outcome of this second strategy. I'm very interested to know the outcome. So let's wait to see the outcome of this second strategy. In addition, I too want to know the Eurobarometer and see what European citizens think, see what their concern is and whether they are willing to pay more to improve animal welfare. But above all, I want to say that, after that evaluation, we will have to see what the result is. I think we have a strict regulation. We must see whether the Member States are approaching it equally and, moreover, I hope that we will be aware of whether or not we are so demanding in agreements with third countries.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab To begin with, I would like to remind you that only nine of the nineteen actions contained in the 2012-2015 animal protection and welfare strategy have been implemented so far. Therefore, the Commission should not only make up for delays in this regard, but should also propose new, harmonised, updated and comprehensive legal standards in order to fully implement the requirements of Article 13 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the Union. Such EU-wide legal standards in this area will ensure a level playing field for livestock farmers in the Union and thus contribute to improving the functioning of the internal market. In such a situation, the Commission should also, when negotiating bilateral trade agreements with third countries, ensure that they comply with European animal welfare rules when exporting both livestock and animal products intended for marketing in the European Union. Unfortunately, without third-country exporters complying with such rules, EU livestock production will be increasingly threatened.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the fact that this issue is being put on the agenda. It is important that Parliament can debate this ahead of the work of the European Commission.  Animal welfare is an important issue for Europeans. Our citizens are increasingly seeking to consume responsibly. They also require to know the origin of food products and the conditions under which they arrive on their plates. In this sense, it is necessary for me to commend the efforts and progress made by the various sectors. In addition, breeders are involved in animal welfare, inseparable from quality production.  If the Commission is to continue its work with the development of a new strategy, it will have to be pragmatic and objective, including all stakeholders, professionals and consumers. In other words, it should not point the finger at those involved in the livestock sectors but should promote good practices and encourage progress.  On the other hand, as I have already pointed out many times, we cannot argue, on the one hand, in favour of animal welfare and, on the other hand, impose disproportionate constraints on our breeders. It is essential to ensure consistency between the laws we are putting in place and the consequences they can have on livestock models in Europe. The demands already made to the breeders must be taken into account.  The example of the NEC directive on Member States' emissions caps for the main pollutants is indicative of the difficulty of aligning the objectives with the reality on the ground. Indeed, the consumer wants both the reduction of greenhouse gases and the breeding of outdoors. However, methane capture requires either locking up cows or intubating them, a contradictory and incompatible situation. I'll let you imagine the difficulty...

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for his "Despite the crisis, despite the economic crisis, we need to talk about animal welfare." A few years ago, for example, when it came to the 2012-2015 strategy, I began my remarks. At that time, too, an economic crisis led us to try to dictate that we should not be concerned with the issues of animal welfare and welfare. Even less can we let our agenda – our thinking and action – be dictated by terrorist, by brutal murderous attacks. We must be on our agenda here in this House and formulate these concerns, which are important to us, also in the face of the crisis, also in the face of terror. Today it is a question of implementing an important point of the European Treaty, namely Article 13. He says: Animals are sentient beings. We cannot ignore them, and I am firmly convinced that you and your team will put a strategy for the future on the table, because you are convinced – and I know this from your work in connection with the Committee on Health – that animal welfare and human welfare, animal health and human health are inseparable. We will only have a Europe for people together if we also have a Europe in which animal welfare and animal rights are paramount.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: – Madam President, we have the strictest animal welfare rules in the world, but if they are not enforced, they are worthless. Therefore, enforcement is key. There is no point in having another animal welfare strategy unless we recognise that the existing rules are widely ignored and that they are often only given lip service in many Member State ministries. We see this problem across animal welfare legislation, for example in animal transport rules, where spot checks have shown that the reality is miles away from the legislation. The case of puppy-smuggling is another example: here, existing regulations to prevent unhealthy animals being transported across Europe are not being respected and the pet passport scheme is being abused. We do not need new legislation; more new legislation which we cannot enforce will just make a mockery of all animal welfare legislation. We need existing legislation to be properly enforced, and to do this, the Commission needs to be much stronger with those reticent Member States; we need to share best practices between Member States; and we need to foster a culture of animal welfare throughout Europe. Only by doing this will we reach common standards at the highest level, not at the lowest.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – European farmers, as well as European agricultural policy, can be proud of what has been done in the field of animal welfare over the last ten, fifteen years.  I myself have closely followed these developments in my country, in the Republic of Slovenia, as a farmer or – if you will – also as agricultural minister. And I know the efforts of farmers to change the stables, both in cattle farming, in pig farming and in poultry, and I think that a lot of progress has really been made and significant resources have also been contributed from European agricultural money. In the next steps, it is surely necessary to see first of all what we have written down, what has already been done, the steps that no one has ever taken, we need to talk about, to make them, to make agriculture in Europe united and to have an assurance that there is also a single animal welfare policy behind European agriculture.  The next steps are certainly necessary, together with farmers, as well as with consumers, to speak out and to move forward so clearly, not to be too fast. On the other hand, I think it is absolutely necessary that we are very critical and that we also put under the microscope of those countries from which we import meat products, because, in the case of uncompromising and uncritical imports of such products, we will also be putting European agriculture, European livestock production at great risk, and, as has already been said today, small farms will fail in areas with difficult production conditions.  However, it will certainly be necessary to pay attention to these animal welfare standards even in all trade agreements, because there is a new trap that, thanks to the patchy rules, the European farmer can pull the short side again.

name: Paul BRANNEN
text: – Madam President, European citizens are looking to the Commission for decisive action to safeguard animal welfare. The new animal welfare strategy should be a starting point to introduce European framework legislation on animal welfare, supported by a one-stop-shop for animal welfare within the Commission – the only guarantee that animal welfare issues will be dealt with in a coordinated and efficient manner. Animals, as we have heard tonight, are sentient beings, and this principle must underpin the thinking around the new animal welfare strategy. Only having realised this basic truth can we address the most pressing animal welfare issues across the EU and beyond: to improve the welfare of farm animals, to end live exports to third countries and to curb the illicit trade in puppies and exotic pets. These, and many other issues, demand attention. It is time for a new and robust strategy.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. For me, the question arises: why not? Why should there not be a new strategy for animal welfare? What is the background? Not only in this committee, when it comes to the strategy for animal welfare, but also in other committees, we as a Parliament must learn that strategies are no longer being put in place. I would like to mention as another example the strategy for gender equality in Europe. Why not? Why is the Commission blocking the setting out very clear objectives, a very clear way, an action plan with data, so that we can really see what progress is in Europe? It is inconceivable to me that these many issues, which have been raised by my fellow Members, would simply flounder. We need a clear framework and we need a strategy. I must honestly say that I very much appreciate the area of human medicine that you are working on. I call on you here once again to act in a similarly clear manner in the field of animal welfare. We need a strategy, and we need it immediately!

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Madam President, animal welfare measures are indeed very important and their continuity must be ensured, although there can obviously be disputes as to its legal or procedural form. However, coherence between innovation, education and the various financial funds should be a priority in the development of the strategy. I note that animal welfare standards in the EU are already outstanding, as my colleague De Castro said, so that we can reduce the negative effects of intensive livestock farming. Of course, this high level is very difficult to raise further, and let us not forget that most farm animals would no longer be able to live in domesticated natural environments. Rather, we should encourage countries outside the EU to take over our practices.  However, the strategy could also include references to pets, parliament and the European Parliament have already highlighted the need for this in 2012, but there is still no coherence between the legislation. Let us not be more lenient in their case simply because we do not eat them.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Animal Welfare Strategy 2012-2015 has had a positive impact on the measures and actions taken to improve the living conditions of animals. Fortunately, the mentality is changing and the attention and sensitivity to animal welfare is increasing. In truth, public opinion is way ahead of the institutions and we have a duty to listen to those who place cases and situations of perpetuated violence and enormous cruelty on us.  This year we managed to adopt the animal health regulation, in which we have clearly written that health cannot ignore the general conditions in which animals find themselves: a mistreated animal can never, ever be a healthy animal. We have taken a first major step and today we are asking the Commission to continue in this direction. We need to develop a strategy that addresses the situations and cases of cruelty and violence, which must be affected and stopped: I am thinking of the slaughter of the Faroe Islands, which must end and as soon as possible.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Madam President, how far should we go in terms of animal welfare legislation? It is an issue that has been based on a compromise between improving the physical and psychological health conditions of animals and the financial impact on producers. With the intensification of production, we can never give in to the objectives of continuously improving animal welfare. As for the welfare of aquatic animals, it is necessary to ensure that aquaculture production, and especially intensive ones, has the right conditions. We know that some conditions of stupendous action are at least questionable.  I therefore ask the Commission to indicate the results of scientific research, obtained under the aegis of the 2012-2015 strategy. There are also issues related to animal suffering during the fishing process. I point out that this issue was silent in the 2012 Commission and it was worth starting its reflection for the future.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: – We have the subject of animal welfare today and I think it is a very important subject and we need to address it. Whether we mean animals that are kept in large-scale animals, which are kept in conditions that are not quite satisfactory, but also pets. Several of my colleagues have already mentioned this. For them, too, we should be able to find the right breeding rate. I would also like to touch on issues that are not resolved, and these are various inappropriate methods of slaughter or various unnecessary sometimes even animal experiments. Although, let's be clear, if it were a new drug that, thanks to testing, would be necessary for humans, our children, we would find the right measure. On the other hand, for example, we make big mistakes in transporting animals. I would also like to touch on the question of cloned animals. They are suffering greatly, they are in great pain, they are in great difficulty, and I am pleased that Parliament has refused to produce meat from cloned animals.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, achieving a high level of animal welfare is an essential element in protecting their health and ensuring their productivity. The European Union's animal protection and welfare strategy 2012-2015 was certainly a step forward, but much remains to be done.  The Commission is called upon to draw up a new and more ambitious strategy for the protection of animal welfare in the period 2016-2020, presenting a proposal for a simplified legislative framework: the current national animal welfare rules, due to their complexity and divergent interpretations, create legal uncertainty and a competitive disadvantage for producers. Greater harmonisation at Community level is therefore necessary.  At the same time, the Commission's desirable proposal must be aimed at giving strong support to farmers who respect the rules and good practices of animal husbandry and who invest in better agricultural structures and should cover all animals in captivity and abandoned, including stray animals of domestic species, with the ultimate aim of finally achieving greater and general animal welfare.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the protection of animal welfare is a very important issue that the Commission must take into account. The European Union's animal protection and welfare strategy for 2012-2015 has 2012-2015 brought several positive results in helping to eradicate the phenomenon of animal torture. But often throughout Europe we encounter torture and ill-treatment of animals. It should also be pointed out that globally animals are literally tortured and succumbing with terrible pains to the altar of obscenity as is the case with whaling.  The European Commission should therefore take multiple additional measures with a view to animal welfare and, of course, to protect them from all kinds of torture practices or similar practices leading to the mistreatment of animals.  Finally, there should be a proposal for a simplified european Union legislative framework for animal welfare.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which I welcome everything that contributes to animal welfare, and this is also a top priority for the vast majority of farmers within the EU. Animal husbandry has developed excellently over the last thirty years. We have made great strides, and the investment programmes that have been put in place to encourage farmers to invest in modern stable farming have also been good instruments. Switzerland, for example, certifies barn techniques that promote animal welfare in particular. That, too, would be an approach for us. We need feasible ways and actionable processes. Common markets must not be lost. However, I already see a major problem in the fact that we treat animal welfare so differently within the 28 Member States. We need harmonisation here. I would like to see an animal husbandry licence introduced for all pet owners. Farmers have a good education, and every private owner should have it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – Madam President, animal welfare attacks are a consequence of agriculture increasingly subject to the logic of profit in an increasingly competitive global market. The absurd levels of productive intensity that we have in the European Union, whether at the level of laying hens or the intensive production of pigs, birds or rabbits, are not the result of any whim on the part of our farmers. It is a contingency that forces them to maximise animal productivity, even if they simply fail to guarantee the profitability of their farms.  It is this contingency that is yet to be resolved. A contradiction between an increasingly liberal, market-oriented Common Agricultural Policy that pushes farmers towards production models where profit overlaps with animal welfare, and also all the scientific evidence that alerts us every day to the need to stop this madness. Stop in the name of animal welfare, biodiversity and public health.  It is therefore important to extend our agricultural equation to other social and environmental variables in the name of the survival of our planet.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, subsidiarity would suggest that decisions should be taken as close as possible to the citizen. Most issues which have been raised today – however nobly – could be dealt with better by nations themselves. One—size—fits—all laws are not always necessary. For example, Member States need to have the power to end live animal imports and exports in their own countries in order to deal with this cruelty. I raise also comments about exotic pets, and particularly the threat that any legislation could have to ornamental fish in the UK, and to thousands of jobs, including some in my constituency which could be affected. Finally, I would say that sensible debate is needed. Sadly, in the United Kingdom we have seen alarmism from the Labour Party, with the shadow cabinet member responsible having suggested that meat be treated like tobacco, with public health campaigns to stop people eating it. I suspect that with those comments she offended meat eaters and smokers alike.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened very carefully and with close attention to your interventions on this important subject, and I share your view that the European Union should continue to be active on animal welfare. I hear different approaches and proposals: for a framework animal welfare law, a new animal strategy, or a European Union platform for animal welfare with strong enforcement, or a situation to evaluate today’s strategy. All those options have been and are being discussed in my Cabinet and with the services, and we have decided to start with a Eurobarometer survey. This is not only a matter of interest for the general public but is also about creating added value – innovation enclosed in the European Union food chain – and therefore concerns a wide range of stakeholders. In the light of the completion of the European Union strategy on animal welfare, new information will become available in 2016 that could allow a response to the many varied yet legitimate expectations of European Union citizens and stakeholders. In addition, proper enforcement of the European Union acquis will continue to be a key priority. A study to be completed soon, and the result of the next Eurobarometer survey, will also look at what role responsible education and information to citizens can play in this regard. With the forthcoming adoption of the proposal on official control, the European Union will have the opportunity to create European reference centres for animal welfare, giving a strong impetus for promoting the issue among stakeholders. Furthermore, I believe that European Union animal production must seek to profit from its advantageous position as a world leader on animal welfare to drive forward this trend and to further explore markets, calling for high standards for animal welfare. I am looking forward to the resolution of this Parliament. In conclusion, let me reassure Parliament that the Commission takes animal welfare issues very seriously. We will continue to work on integrating these issues into the wider perspective for the future of the European Union food chain.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: Motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the rules of Procedure will be announced later. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 26 March 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. I regret to note the lack of ambition of the proposal. A number of principles must be clearly enshrined both in the Treaties and in practice: full compliance by European and national legislation with Article 18 TFEI, that is to say, that animals should be regarded as sentient beings; the gradual but definitive abandonment of animal experimentation, the validity of which is contested by many scientific studies, respecting the demands of "Stop Vivisection" ; a ban on the use of wild animals in circus shows, where they are forced to live an unnatural and mortifying existence – requires the uniformity of national rules that already exist in 18 Member States; a concrete commitment to the closure of all dolphinarics, where cetaceans with the highest degree of intelligence and sociality are locked up for life; the improvement, including through the appropriate allocation of CAP funds, of the conditions under which animals are used for rural development. As a member of the Intergroup on Animal Welfare, I will try, together with the M5S Europe Delegation, to continue this civil struggle.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. I fully agree with the position of the European People's Party that, at a time when Europe's security has been shaken and cooperation is needed in all areas, it is unnecessary and pointless to debate animal welfare issues, possible 'problems'. The above is also supported by the fact that the eu currently has the highest animal welfare requirements on Earth, so the EU sets an example to the world in this area. Rather, an effective solution should be found on how to make it more difficult to enter the EU of foods in which animals are not kept on the basis of requirements that are not in compliance with EU rules. This is about the competitiveness of farmers who meet strict animal welfare standards, so the European Commission and the other EU institutions and agencies must do their uts to allow only food produced in accordance with EU rules to enter the EU.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. – Animal welfare is a topic on which constituents from my region are continuously writing me, on issues ranging from addressing badger cull and fox hunting in the UK, over life animal exports, to bull fighting in Spain, the situation of stray dogs in Romania and whaling in the Faroe Islands. This proves the trust vested in EU institutions to take action on a topic that is close to people’s hearts. While I acknowledge the important role played by the Commission in improving animal welfare over the past years, crucial steps remain to be taken. The recognition that animals are sentient beings should be the basis of any effective piece of legislation aiming to protect the wellbeing of animals. Yet the majority of existing acts fail to recognise this key principle. And while the adoption by the Commission of a Strategy on the Protection and Welfare of Animals 2012 - 2015 has been a crucial step in improving animal welfare, it is disappointing that only 9 out of the 19 actions contained in it have been implemented. I count on the Commission to build on progress it has made with a strategy for 2016-2020 that investigates why this has been the case and draws lessons from failure as well as success.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Commission Communication on the EU Animal Protection and Welfare Strategy 2012-2015 was a step in the right direction as it was a road map with concrete action on EU animal welfare policy. It is good that the Commission has taken into account the comments of the European Parliament in its Resolution of May 2010. Unfortunately, so far only 9 out of 19 actions planned by the Commission have been implemented. The Commission must implement the missing elements of the 2012-2015 strategy as soon as possible. Efforts in this regard should continue. I expect the Commission to present a new proposal on animal welfare for 2016-2020. Better implementation of EU law is also needed. I would like to point out that harmonisation of rules must not lead to lower standards. Animal abuse cannot be justified in any way. I therefore expect the Commission to ban animal abuse without exception throughout the European Union. The provisions on the protection of live animals and during transport should be updated on the basis of Parliament Resolution 2012/2031. The Commission should also ensure that animal welfare standards are included in negotiated agreements with third countries and respected by non-EU exporters.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. – The debate on a European animal welfare strategy is important in several respects. On the one hand, it is good that we Europeans can, even in the context of terrorist attacks, discuss specific aspects of building the future of Europe. At the same time, it is a pity that the important issue of animal welfare, which is directly linked not only to values, but to the stomach of almost every European, is only addressed late Monday evening. With regard to the document being prepared, I would like to ask the honourable Commissioner how, in the new strategy, the Commission intends to ensure that all the measures envisaged for the welfare of the population are implemented in the period 2016-2020. If I am not mistaken, only five of the 19 measures envisaged in the current strategy have been fully implemented. After all, this issue affects not only the well-being of animals, but also the quality of food! The second point that I would like to draw your attention to is the very subject of the question. We are discussing the regulation of the welfare of animals, particularly those used for food. But do we not think that, if we are too intrusive in animal welfare regulation, we are no longer paying sufficient attention to the welfare of the livestock sector itself? After all, in at least a few Member States, including cases such as pig farming or dairy farming, in my country – Lithuania – individual agricultural areas are successfully approaching the brink of extinction, both because of the market crisis and unfair commercial practices, and because of gaps in national or European regulation and the reluctance to rescue as long as there is something to be rescued.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I will vote in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the motion for a resolution on a new animal welfare strategy for the period 2016-2020. The measures seem to me to be balanced. I will reject the amendments tabled by the Left and the Greens with a view to improving the protection of certain animals – fish, pigs, laying hens, hunting deer, etc. – because they always call for action by the European Commission. I reject that. I am opposed to greater shifts of competences to the EU. The EU should not set any targets. So I do not rule out the possibility that I could support individual projects at national level. However, the EU should live on its diversity, which is best ensured by finding different solutions to difficult and controversial issues – that is, less EU, more self-determination.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Inês Cristina Zuber on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on reducing inequalities with a special focus on child poverty (2014/2237(INI)) (A8-0310/2015).

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, in the European Union, more than one in four children are currently at risk of poverty or social exclusion. In 2013, 26.5 million children in the European Union were at risk of falling into poverty and social exclusion. These are dramatic numbers. The policies that have impoverished the families of the European Union are the same ones that have thrown children into poverty, denying them many of the rights contained in the Convention on the Rights of the Child, including the rights to health, education and social protection.  In this report we make clear what the various studies have pointed out, but it seems that those who have insisted on austerity policies, called fiscal consolidation, have ignored it. The main factors contributing to child poverty are wealth redistribution policies, the effectiveness of government intervention through income support. It is clear that increasing employment is the most effective tool in the fight against poverty. It is clear that the degradation of wage policies and social protection systems at national level increases child poverty. But the job alone is not enough. The drama of today is that the risk of child poverty persists in families with high employment intensity, such as Romania, Lithuania, Portugal, Spain and others. Today it is known that working parents who do not have access to crèches are often forced to leave children in the care of another child or to resort to paid and uncertified in-service networks, which calls into question the safety and well-being of children.  Therefore, in this report we recommend that Member States legislate social rights, including an appropriate mandatory minimum wage that respects national practices and collective agreements and provides greater security for families and combats precarious links by promoting work with social rights.  That is why in this report we call on the European Commission to refrain from recommending reformulations and cuts in the public administration of the Member States, to promote the flexibilization of labour relations and the privatisation of public services, which have unequivocally led to the weakening of children's social rights.  But in this report there is a fundamental perspective: that effective poverty prevention policies are those that guarantee universal and free access to public services, not those that only care about compensating children already in child poverty. Studies show that universal support policies offer better protection against child poverty. Thus, in this report, we advocate public, free and universal services of high quality, particularly with regard to childcare, education, health, housing and leisure activities. We therefore advocate universal social subsidies for children, as their own intrinsic right. We encourage legislation that protects or increases maternity and paternity rights, safeguards women's return to work after pregnancy and maternity leave, and supports single-parent families, which are mostly female. In our report we consider not only monetary poverty, but also multidimensional deprivation, and therefore we advocate statistical methods that integrate multidimensional indicators. We also believe that better use of the European Union Structural Funds should be made to combat child poverty. We will vote against the parties that have been included in the report who believe that this tragedy can be resolved through the European Semester or the rules of economic and monetary union, because we believe that what causes the problem to a great deal must be tackled and cannot be part of the solution. Finally, we would like to thank all those who have contributed to this report, including to various Portuguese and international organisations that fight child poverty on a daily basis.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – Thank you very much, Honourable President, for the floor. I support the report because I believe that all children should be guaranteed the right to education, to healthcare, to housing and to grow up in a caring family environment. Unfortunately, however, the reality is different, as more than one in four children in the European Union are at risk of poverty and social exclusion.  The report states in its content that poverty among children is expected to deepen at the expense of austerity measures. Austerity measures are, of course, necessary, but they must not go to the expense of children. It is therefore for each Member State to provide at least basic needs for a normal childhood.  The consequences of excessive austerity at the expense of children can, of course, also affect public health and then on to the Treasury.  However, I would also like to highlight the example of Slovenia, which I think is still a country that ensures the accessibility of public health to all children.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Madam President, poverty, especially among children, is not only a matter of money because it does not only mean the lack of food, clothes, access to decent housing, but is often linked to social exclusion and lack of access to quality health and education. Particular attention should be paid to children living with single parents, especially single mothers who often care for other family members with special needs. We must not forget for a moment that the protection of families and, in particular, single-parent families with children with health problems is and must remain a reference point in European policies. As such, I support the importance of public prevention policies that invest in judicious solutions for the well-being of children, with a focus on reducing early school leaving, supporting the formation of autonomous people capable of integrating into society and the labour market.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, the welfare of all our citizens is, I believe, high on the list of priorities for all of us in this home. However, while I consider the rapporteur's intentions to be good and noble, I believe that the proposed measures are completely wrong. Namely, further insistence on measures that led to the problem cannot be the solution, but only the source of new problems. Free healthcare and education sounds very nice for everyone, but it should be remembered that such a thing simply does not exist. These services come at a price and someone has to pay for it, and that someone is a taxpayer. Their continued burden on new levies due to increased public spending would lead solely to job closures and the flight of talent from Europe. We can only reduce inequality if we give those most vulnerable the opportunity to rise with their knowledge and work, while ensuring that they are not discriminated against, but protected by the rule of law. Putting whole social strata on social will only increase inequality and, more importantly, deepen misunderstanding and the gap between citizens.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, the long-standing economic crisis is taking its toll on many areas. Children are probably, in the long run, the biggest casualty of this long economic crisis we are witnessing. Therefore, I want to make it clear that this report, which I fundamentally support although some things are not fully realistic, I believe because one wants to have the welfare of the child in the foreground and the well-being of children in general, shows that there are differences between our states – differences between east and west, differences between north and south. And what that report notes is, unfortunately, absolutely true.  But I also want to say that there are solutions. I see the synergy that the European Union, member states, but let's never forget the local and regional authorities when we talk about kindergartens, nursegers, schools, the health system, give for the benefit of children.

name: Laura AGEA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we have reached a time when we must acknowledge that the world is not changing with our words but with our example.  If we really consider that the only beauty that can save this world is children, it is necessary at this point to make courageous choices, choices due, because the well-being, health and dignity of children must become the only priority of this House, of the Commission and of all those actors who, uniquely, can really help to protect children in every possible way.  There are no choices that cannot and must not be made: any courageous, innovative, new choice must be made. Children deserve every effort. We must give them a different world from the one in which we live.  That is why we support Mrs Zuber's report, which we thank for her cooperation.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, while this report on reducing child poverty does not have direct legislative implications, it is undoubtedly a very strong appeal to the Institutions of the European Union and the Member States. I would like to thank Mrs Zuber for her very accommodating approach to the amendments and for the consensus we have reached.  Children's poverty depends on their families, their parents. That is why the report also appeals to families, to creating better conditions for childcare, to employment, to housing affordability, to affordable healthcare for families. Improving their education and, ˗ particular, completing secondary education, is the way out of poverty and the way to a better perspective for children. The quality of education is one of the main tools for reducing poverty. This is also related to the proposal for free meals, other school services and extracurricular activities. I think it also has to do with tinging with the migration crisis and the care of the children who come here.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, from the outset I would like to stress the importance of the report we are debating and to congratulate the rapporteur and all those who have worked on this report. I wanted to talk about this report to highlight the urgent need for social investment and policies to combat child poverty. "Investing in children: breaking the vicious circle of disfavor" – must not remain a slogan. There is too much increase in the risk of poverty or social exclusion. The data show that the number of children at risk of poverty has increased by around one million in four years, which is not at all safe for the future of Europe. More than 26 million children in the European Union are exposed to poverty. Children ensure the replacement of future generations, and if we don't care how they live, how they have access to education and health, we cannot ensure future generations. There is still a large school dropout – between 13 and 20%, millions of children do not have access to health, child trafficking still exists and needs careful monitoring. I believe that the European Commission must propose instruments to measure these indicators, but also measures to eliminate them.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: – Thank you for the floor, President-in-Office.  As a society, we are responsible for the welfare of children, and it is for all of us to fully exercise the Convention on the Rights of the Child, which puts at the heart of the interest, protection and the right of children.  We have a duty of the Signatory States to ensure that every child is protected from all forms of violence, abuse, neglect, cruel treatment and exploitation. It is also very important that we actively cooperate and raise people's awareness of the fight against child trafficking, for any type of exploitation, which often includes forced labour, forced marriages, illegal adoptions and sexual abuse.  The most effective solution to reduce rising child poverty is in the developing economy, in the rise of economic growth and in tackling unemployment. The economic crisis has an impact on the rise in child poverty and on the exercise of children's rights under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur Ms Zuber for this comprehensive report on child poverty. We have taken note of your analysis and we do share your concerns about the high levels of child poverty in many of our Member States. As you have pointed out, the risk of poverty and social exclusion is greater for children than for adults. Child poverty is a multifaceted issue that demands an integrated and – to the extent possible – preventive approach, looking at both the employment situation of the household and also the rights of the child. The fight against child poverty has been high on our agenda. In 2013, the Commission proposed the Recommendation ‘Investing in children: breaking the cycle of disadvantage’, which is currently being implemented by Member States. The Commission will keep working to ensure the full operationalisation of this recommendation. In this respect we take note of your suggestion to have a three-pillar approach: access to resources, services and children’s participation. We are also monitoring child-poverty related aspects in the context of the European Semester. In its 2013 recommendation, the Commission suggested that the best way to support parents and their children is through progressive universalism, which is a system of strong universal services and benefit rights topped up with targeted instruments for particularly disadvantaged groups, such as the Roma. The recommendation calls on the Member States to provide parents with access to resources, in the form of paid work and adequate family and child benefits, and to high-quality services such as early childhood education and care, health and housing. An integrated approach is key to ensuring children have the best start in life. The Commission has also been regularly monitoring the Member States’ progress towards the Barcelona targets to improve access to childcare. Good-quality childcare services have been shown to support the cognitive and social development of children, especially those from low-income backgrounds, and improve their academic and labour market opportunities later on in life. These services are therefore key to reducing the intergenerational transmission of poverty. Many Member States have made good efforts to improve the provision of these services, but progress is still slow and uneven. We are providing country-specific recommendations to many Member States where needed. In 2014 and 2015 many Member States received country-specific recommendations to improve income support for families, to expand childcare, as well as to make education more inclusive and to reduce financial disincentives for parents to enter employment. As far as creating a new financial instrument in this area is concerned, we would like to recall that there are already funding opportunities for children in the current European Structural and Investment Funds: the European Social Fund, the European Regional Development Fund, and others. These instruments have been, in fact, significantly strengthened for the current 2014-2020 programming period. Member States should make further efforts to use them to their full potential. In addition, Member States have agreed that 25.6% of the European Social Fund allocation of EUR 86 billion is to be earmarked for social inclusion measures, of which EUR 8 billion is set aside for access to children’s and childcare services and for measures fighting against early school leaving. In this regard, it is important that all key stakeholders at national, regional and local level are mobilised and form strong partnerships. The European Union funds are also supporting healthy nutrition for children. With the European Union School Fruit Scheme, EUR 150 million will support the distribution of fruit and vegetables in schools for 2015 and 2016. With these funds we can reach 12 million children across 25 Member States. In addition, there is national or private co-funding, estimated to amount to around EUR 32 million. All these financial interventions are extremely important for preventing and breaking the intergenerational transmission of poverty and social exclusion. As you know, the Commission is currently working on a European pillar of social rights to foster upward convergence of employment and social performance in the European Union. We want to ensure that our legislation and policy framework is in line with the realities of modern life – teleworking, digital work, combining work and family duties – and keeps pace with developments in the fast-changing labour market, adequately addressing needs and challenges arising from diverse and innovative forms of work, and that it invests in people through a modernised social framework for those in and out of work. We are also preparing a fresh start for working parents and caregivers. We believe that this new approach will reap benefits for all; in particular, for working parents and other caregivers who seek a better balance to their work and life commitments, but also for women, to support their participation in the labour market. Finally, as the employment status of parents is one of the key determinants of child poverty, this initiative will contribute to reducing the number of children who live in households at risk of poverty. Let me assure you once again that this Commission is committed to addressing child poverty across the European Union by restoring economic growth and upward social convergence, fostering job creation and ensuring social fairness. These are not mere abstract concepts. For the 40% of children in some of our Member States who live in households at risk of poverty, we need to come with effective solutions to foster employment of their parents and to ensure their full participation in society.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 25 November 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I support the resolution because we must send out a clear signal against child poverty and its social exclusion. Unfortunately, child poverty is widespread in the EU – even in Germany. Poverty is not just a question of money, so that basic needs such as food, clothing and housing can be satisfied. Child poverty is also linked to social exclusion and lack of access to quality education and health services. Children are our future and it is our responsibility to give them free access to high-quality education. The EU is one of the strongest economies on earth, there can be no excuse for children to be malnourished even in one of our Member States.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – The European Parliament's report on the eradication of child poverty calls for European solutions in a number of important areas, of which adequate catering and access to education and health care are of paramount importance. However, country-specific proposals for specific and complex problems in the Member States cannot be made in the report and therefore do not go beyond the level of generalisation. Nevertheless, this initial step is an expression of determination, which can become an important factor in Member States where poverty has a major impact on the child population. Currently, at least 550,000 children in Hungary do not have access to daily hot meals during holidays and nearly 50,000 children are starving every day. This makes our country the third worst indicator of child poverty in Europe.  The seriousness of the problem is indicated by the fact that the Hungarian Government views child hunger as a problem it has long solved, and therefore did not support the recently launched civil initiative to eradicate this problem, which all other hungarian parties have stood by; instead, Hungary government swept the initiative off the table on the grounds of political utilitiness. Although the decisions and actions of the European institutions are not a substitute for the active action of the governments of the Member States in the fight against child poverty, it is nevertheless important that the European institutions reflect comprehensively, forward-looking and exemplaryly on the complex and specific problems in the Member States.

name: Jan KELLER
text: Writing. – Currently, one in four children in EU countries is at risk of poverty. Children of long-term unemployed parents, children of single mothers and also children from immigrant families are strongly represented in this category. Child poverty thus becomes one indicator of the degree of effectiveness, or rather the ineffectiveness, of integration policy. Since the beginning of the economic crisis in 2008, the proportion of children living in poverty has increased quite significantly, even in the richest EU countries. There is also an increasing risk of poverty in families where one or both breadwinners are reliant on under-compliant employment contracts. These are the ones that have spread fastest in the labour market in recent years. Unfortunately, the measures proposed by the rapporteur do not take into account the new situation due to the influx of refugees from broken countries. It should be reckoned that it is among them that the risk factors of child poverty (unemployment, under-paid work, incomplete families) will be represented particularly frequently. It is not possible to get an idea of how to deal with the problem of migrant integration from the proposed measures, without prejudice to the chances of addressing the problems of child poverty in the categories of population discussed in the report. For political reasons, it would not be obvious to ignore this challenge.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. – Children living in poverty are not only a problem in developing countries, but also in developed countries. Especially in this period of financial crisis, along with the increase in social inequalities, there is also an increase in the levels of poverty and social exclusion of children, especially in the countries of the European South - which are affected by mercelial austerity.  In particular, according to Eurostat data, Greece ranks 30th among 35 developed countries in relative poverty and the penultimate position in terms of public spending for the family (1.1% of GDP). In addition, compared to 2014 there has been a doubling in the number of minors seeking asylum in Europe in order to escape war zones. Between January and September 2015 some 190,000 children applied for asylum in Europe.  Clearly, all EU states should strengthen universal social benefits for children, such as providing subsidised or free meals to children, develop policies to defend the rights of the child to education, health and protection against violence, and increase the subsidies they give to all children's access to culture and entertainment.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – Today in Europe, 21% of children are at risk of falling into poverty. At least 20 million children are suffering daily from the lack of income and basic services. Many of them do not have a warm meal every day. I support the call of my political group, the Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament, for the introduction of a European Child Guarantee, financed by the EU budget, to lift children out of poverty. The report on inequalities, primarily focused on child poverty and social exclusion, highlights the imperious necessity of establishing EU and national targets that can genuinely indicate the social status of children, alongside their well-being. There must be a strong cohesiveness between existing funds and policies to guarantee children equal access to benefits such as health and education in order to ensure that they achieve their full potential. I therefore emphasise the need mentioned in the report of coordinated action at both European and national levels, as these objectives can only be achieved if awareness is raised at a systemic level and all available resources are aligned and directed towards the same goal – combating child inequality, poverty and social exclusion.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, the great civil—society organisations and everyone else who has contributed to making this report what it is: a great starting point for making the right changes to European cohesion policy in order to make it more inclusive for marginalised communities – or, as Commissioner Crețu put it last week, to make the inclusion of marginalised communities one of the priorities for EU cohesion policy. This report is made for people who very often do not have a lobby in this Parliament and in EU institutions. It is made for people who are very often overlooked and overheard when it comes to the distribution of EU funds. In the preparation of this report, I have seen examples of where this is still happening today in the European Union. In my hometown, Gelsenkirchen, I visited a school where I met two girls – two sisters, Denise and Michaela, 10 and 12 years old – who had recently moved from Romania to Gelsenkirchen. I met them in their class. They were curious, they wanted to learn, and they were really trying to get integrated into the school in Gelsenkirchen. But the question that came up in my head was: will Denise and Michaela have the same chances and opportunities that I had when I was growing up in Gelsenkirchen? Will they have the same access to resources I had? When we look at the situation of Denise and Michaela, there are challenges that they are facing, because very often they are being discriminated against or they are facing structural exclusion. This report can give the tools to cities such as Gelsenkirchen to create an integrated approach in order to give a chance to children like this, be it in education or with regard to housing, employment or health. We need to look at different fields of society in order to give a chance to people from marginalised communities. At the same time, we have to bring all the stakeholders together, be they from the local level, from civil society or the people affected themselves, in order to create the best programmes and to really make sustainable investments. And we need to give support for them to have a strong voice in the whole process – not only in the preparation, but also in the monitoring and evaluation, of the programmes. Secondly, we simply cannot afford to live in segregated societies, because in the long run, inequality and exclusion is much more expensive for us than inclusion and integration. This is why we need to make sure that EU funds actually reach the people that need them the most. This report will give a very clear signal to both the Commission and the Member States to do exactly that. Be it community-led local development or strong implementation of the partnership principle, or be it monitoring our evaluation mechanisms that need to be improved, we have these tools and we need to implement them in order to make EU funds more inclusive. Lastly, alongside the set of good measures and proposals that are in this report, we also need to speak very clearly about the problems. Let us not shy away from clearly mentioning the obstacles that we are still facing to have inclusive societies in the European Union. Be it corruption or fraud, be it the lack of political will or anti-Gypsyism, we need to name these barriers in order to create good implementation and overcome these problems. Human rights are the basis of the European Union. Let us mainstream human rights in all policy fields in this Parliament and make them also the basis of our work with regard to EU structural funds, because in the end, this is going to create societies where everybody has a chance and can live equally. I want to thank again everyone who has contributed to this report and I hope that it will find your support tomorrow in the vote.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, despite the first steps of progress achieved through the EU framework for national Roma integration, the wide gaps in our societies show that there is a lot more to be done to break the vicious circle faced by marginalised communities, especially the Roma: lack of education and diminished labour market prospects coupled with direct and indirect discrimination. Nevertheless, it is also in these vital areas where a better use of cohesion policy could make a difference. Mainstream and targeted measures for the reduction of the rate of Roma early school leavers are among the measures that could have the largest long-term impact, as it is early school leaving which later translates into the lack of skills and qualifications that prevent Roma from accessing quality employment in their adulthood. Similarly, beside demand—side measures such as recruitment subsidies for employment and apprenticeship schemes, lifelong learning and vocational training for adult Roma must also be key priorities in our goal towards more social cohesion.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Madam President, in an increasingly globalised society ensuring equal access to high-quality education for all members of society is essential for reducing social exclusion. The Union and the Member States must strengthen their cooperation in order to implement programmes, projects and support activities for marginalised communities in order to facilitate early childhood education, new opportunities for other forms of education and lifelong learning, taking into account the continuing changes in various sectors and the increase in the percentage of online tools. It is also essential to empower women and girls in marginalised communities for adequate vocational training, and here I am also referring to roma girls and women. Stimulating entrepreneurship and participation among women in these communities, in order to better access the labour market, must become a priority.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the troika of memoranda and merkelic austerity have turned Greece into the most marginalised country in the European Union. So in the last six years there have been huge armies of millions of unemployed people in the country, 40% of the population lives below the poverty line, the unemployed young people of Greece are taking the path of foreign migration to other countries of the European Union, small and medium-sized enterprises are closing by thousands and the rural economy is wintering.  The mercelian austerity that applies to Greece and the countries of the European South have created a two-speed Europe. A Europe of dual interests aimed only at exploiting the wealth of the countries of the South with a view to the economic development of German Europe. This situation in the European Union must therefore be stopped and there must be a Union of equality and equal opportunities for all citizens and the Member States of the Union.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam President, cohesion policy is a partnership policy. The policy of partnership between the European Union, member states, but let's never forget, especially when we talk about marginalised communities or groups, that without the role of local and regional authorities there is no realisation of cohesion policy in the right way. That is why I want to talk about the importance of involving local and regional authorities when we speak specifically and in this report on the resolution of the Roma problem, as one of the marginalised communities within the European Union. I have a lot of experience, personally as an Istrian prefect who has tried for twelve years to help the Roma in Istria and I know for sure that the role of cities and regions in providing concrete assistance to the Roma is extremely important. So I ask you to do everything you can to do this synergy of all the authorities in the European Union.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my colleague for her constructive spirit and for the excellent result she has achieved with this report. Our opinion is very positive, thanks to the particularly interesting and very topical proposals. One of them is the analysis of the phenomenon of marginalisation. It must be done by ascertaining and analysing a number of indicators, such as social exclusion, long-term unemployment, low level of education, poor housing conditions, level of discrimination, exposure to health risks and lack of access to health care.  The tragic events of recent weeks only confirm the importance of measures to reduce the inequalities and conditions of cultural, social and economic isolation that are among the factors responsible for the radicalisation of common and organised crime.  Cohesion policy and the 20% share of European Social Fund resources, which by regulation must be devoted to combating poverty and the social inclusion of the most vulnerable, is of fundamental importance. We cannot allow austerity measures to affect key sectors, such as education, training and housing, and cohesion policy funds not to be used or to be used with projects of dubious use.  The quantity and quality of projects and the real application of the partnership principle matter today more than ever if we do not want the objectives of economic, social and territorial cohesion to become just empty declarations of intent with no practical effect for our regions. I would like to thank the rapporteur once again.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, as a member of the Regional Development Committee, I support the parts of the report that underline that the implementation of cohesion policy must pay particular attention to the key challenges of poverty and exclusion of young people and children and people with disabilities.  I also fully agree with the parts of the report on the bottom-up approach, i.e. the aspiration that EU funds should be used in an integrated way through new territorial development instruments in cohesion policy, integrated territorial investments and community-led local development, as they also highlight the important role that civil society can play in this segment.  However, I believe that the protection of rights and the allocation of funds should not depend on certain subjective and utterly ideological factors such as belonging to arbitrarily selected groups, but solely on objective and above all measurable criteria that must be the same for all.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur, Madam Reintke, and the shadow rapporteurs, Mr Kósa and Mr Urtasun, for their very constructive approach on this own-initiative report. Thank you so much. It supports several of the novelties introduced by the legislative framework for the European Structural and Investment Funds for 2014-2020. These include the fact that funding for social inclusion and poverty reduction should amount to at least 20% of the Member States’ European Social Fund budget. In fact, Member States have allocated 25.6% of the European Social Funds’ total budget – the total budget is about EUR 21 billion – to measures aimed at social inclusion. This includes support for marginalised communities such as the Roma. I welcome the rapporteur’s recommendations, many of which are fully in line with our guidance to Member States. Let me start by stressing that ʽpromoting social inclusion, combating poverty and any discriminationʼ is one of the eleven thematic objectives of the European Strategic and Investment Funds. Under this thematic objective, marginalised communities can receive support through a dedicated investment priority. In fact, Member States have programmed about EUR 1.5 billion under this priority. I am pleased that the report supports the explicit, but not exclusive, approach taken by the Commission in the use of European Strategic and Investment Funds in support to marginalised communities. Other thematic objectives – on education and unemployment – can also be mobilised to enhance European Union financial interventions. The European Strategic and Investment Funds are geared towards delivery on the European Union 2020 targets and the ensuing priorities set out in the country-specific recommendations. A tangible illustration of this is the fact that Member States which received country-specific recommendations on Roma integration have all programmed support under the dedicated investment priority on marginalised communities in their programming documents. The new legislative framework has also ensured that an adequate policy framework is in place before Member States receive actual European Strategic Investment Fund support through so-called ex-ante conditionalities. With regard to the Roma, Member States are required to set up a national Roma inclusion strategic policy framework. This is crucial, as the implementation of national Roma integration strategies in countries with sizeable Roma minorities largely relies on European Social Fund and European Regional Development Fund funding. I would like to refer now to some of the recommendations you made in your report. The report calls on the Commission to guide Member States in defining marginalised communities. I would like to stress that it is the Member States’ responsibility to define the marginalised communities on the basis of national indicators, taking into account their national context. This is based on the assumption that Member States are in a much better position to define the target groups for their support. The report also rightly draws attention to the issue of segregation, a very difficult issue. Spatial and education segregation/desegregation are complex and critical issues which both the European Regional Development Fund and the European Social Fund address. The Commission prepared a guidance note for Member States on the use of European Union funds in tackling segregation. It should help support inclusive education and housing for Roma. Infringement procedures have been launched against some Member States because of discrimination of Roma children in education. The importance the report attaches to the involvement of all relevant partners in the preparation and implementation of programmes is well echoed by the strengthened partnership principle in the Common Provisions Regulation. Its enforcement has been carefully ensured by the Commission during the negotiation phase of the programme. You also mentioned the European Union Urban Agenda, which should help cities to improve the implementation of European Union and national policies on the ground. Following discussions between the Commission, Member State cities, experts and stakeholders, urban poverty has been selected as a priority area where Roma inclusion may play an important role. The reinforcement of the administrative capacities of public and local authorities, which has been identified in the report as a key challenge, can be strongly supported by the funds. A dedicated thematic objective on administrative capacity can be used to support public administration in delivering services to marginalised communities in a more efficient manner. I very much welcome your call to empower marginalised communities and to ensure they can get easier access to European Union funding. I am convinced that a greater use of simplified cost options, fundamentally simplifying the management of the funds, as well as territorial approaches, including community-led local development, will play a crucial role in ensuring such better access. Finally, the report rightfully underlines the added value of transnational cooperation and exchange of good practices. This will be reflected in the new URBACT programme as well as in the new European Social Fund transnational cooperation framework. As a final note, I would like to stress once more that it is the Commission’s firm intention to steer the European Union towards social fairness. This requires that no citizen can be left behind.
