I therefore express in the strongest terms possible my commitment to use all means at the European Union’s disposal to reach the Union’s marginalised communities. And we are very grateful that this report helps us stay on the right path.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Tuesday 24 November 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. – Many people face different forms of discrimination, especially in Roma communities that are often marginalised in European societies. I have tabled, together with a number of colleagues, an amendment on the financing of programmes to combat anti-Gypsy attitudes and ensure their better integration into society. I would like to thank all colleagues who will support this amendment in advance. Some communities do not benefit from European cohesion policy. They are not included in decision-making structures or in project implementation and monitoring processes. This can lead to a situation where the EU is exacerbating the problems of vulnerable groups, which is why the Commission needs to rethink the use of cohesion funds to meet the needs of marginalised communities.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – The EU should be more consistent in its cohesion policy. The Commission should not drive small peripheral Member States towards further marginalisation, as it recently did by issuing its damning decision regarding Estonian Air. Unlike in the Air Malta and Cyprus Airways cases, the Commission did not accept Estonia’s ‘peripheral geographic location’ as a justification for state aid although these cases are extremely similar. According to their previous decision: ‘the Commission notes that Air Malta as a small carrier with a fleet of only 10 aircraft which does not have much possibility to benefit from synergies and which additionally intends to meet specific needs due to Malta’s peripheral geographical situation is not comparable with major flag carriers or large LCCs’ and that Air Malta is ‘vital for Malta’s economic and social cohesion both internally and with the rest of the EU by providing daily transportation’. Estonian Air was even smaller with only 6 aircraft serving a country of 1.3 million on the periphery of Europe, which is why it is astonishing that the Commission decided to ignore all the decisive arguments forming its own previous decisions and did not consider Estonia to be in a situation comparable to Cyprus and Malta.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Paavo Väyrinen, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the role of the EU in the UN – how to better achieve the EU's foreign policy objectives (2015/2104(INI)) (A8-0308/2015).

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, my report includes several proposals for strengthening the role of the United Nations system in global governance and for improving the possibilities of the European Union and its Member States to better achieve our foreign policy goals inside the system. The report paves the way for an annual process in which Parliament can address the global challenges in a deep and comprehensive way. For me personally, the most important achievements in this report are the recommendations on the substantial strengthening of the economic, social, environmental and developmental dimensions of the UN system. According to the report, this must be done in the first instance by means of structural and functional reform of the Economic and Social Council, but we also call on the EU institutions and Member States to consider the possibility of strengthening their role in the ECOSOC by developing it into a Sustainable Development Council. My draft was more ambitious. I wanted to give the Sustainable Development Council the same kind of status as the Security Council in dealing with all areas of global cooperation other than security. I proposed that the Council would have permanent members: the European Union, the USA, Japan and the BRICS countries and rotating ones. These ideas got a lot of support in the negotiations, but not enough in order to be accepted. This basic idea is not a new one: it was originally launched in the Rio Conference in 1992. It was then watered down by establishing only the Commission on Sustainable Development under the ECOSOC. Chancellor Angela Merkel proposed, in a speech to the World Economic Council in Davos in 2009, the creation of a UN Economic Council according to the model of the UN Security Council. I have in mind a council with a wider mandate covering all economic, social, environmental and human development in the world. When Barack Obama started his term as President of the United States with Hillary Clinton as his Foreign Secretary, he introduced the idea of ‘three Ds’ in US Foreign and Security Policy: development was lifted to an equal footing with defence and diplomacy. Now we should do the same in the European Union. In the negotiations on my EU—UN report, I felt that those who emphasise the importance of the security dimension of the United Nations were reluctant to strengthen the other parts of the UN system. I even heard the argument that they do not belong to the area of foreign policy, even if they have a prominent position in the foreign and security policy goals section in the EU Treaty and development has a more central role in strengthening security all over the world. In the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET), a report is going to be drafted on the global security strategy of the EU. I think that we should pay a lot of attention to development issues also in that report. In the case of the EU, the defence pillar cannot have a dominant role. We have to rely more on diplomacy and development.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, we are discussing the role of the European Union within the UN, which is known to protect human rights and promote economic and social development. However, development and the fight against poverty need resources, which in developing countries and in the countries of the European region do not exist, since the repayment of state debts goes to the loan lenders and thus the economic life of these countries has dried up.  That is why the UN General Assembly decision which last September decided on procedures for restructuring and writing off the state debts of developing countries should enter into force. However, this decision of the UN General Assembly was not voted for by any member country of the European Union, not even the heavily indebted countries of the European South, as they followed the orders of Brussels, the troika and international lenders.  It has therefore emerged that the European Union is shedding crocodile tears for the UN and all it cares about is its narrow economic interests and nothing else.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, first of all I want to protest. It is inappropriate for us to discuss this report and the role of the European Union in the United Nations as a brief report. Today we discussed our relations in the World Trade Organization, Ecuador's approach to our Agreement with Colombia and Peru, we discussed our relationship with Vietnam, and we discuss our relationship with the United Nations as part of a brief report. That's inappropriate. Unacceptable.  The role of the European Union within the United Nations must first and foremost be an attempt to always get one vote, to act as one voice, for Europe to be credible, for Europe to be strong at the United Nations and to impose its themes because of course it is not only the security of the United Nations themes and it cannot only be security, but it must also be the development and social component and protection of the environment. Climate change, it's enough just to say what it means when we talk about environmental protection.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, it takes a very segmented and very biased reading of the Charter of the United Nations to consider – as this report does – that the European Union is reviewed in its principles and values. What can we say, for example, of military aggression against sovereign and independent countries such as Iraq, Libya, Syria, actively promoted and carried out also by countries of the European Union?  Two examples that this report does not address on the role of the European Union, which the European Union has been playing at the United Nations General Assembly, where it should not have a seat. The first example: the discussion on a multilateral framework for the restructuring of sovereign debts. An issue of the utmost importance for several countries of the European Union. What does the European Union do? It does not follow the very important discussion and boycotts it from various points of view, seeking that no substantive conclusions come out of it. Another issue: the resolution on the right to public water and sanitation. What has the European Union done? What have the countries of the European Union done? Once again they did not approve this very important resolution and were left with an ambiguous abstention in most cases, not adopting those important principles against the privatization of water and water services.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, I find the concepts of this report deeply worrying, not least the usual display of neo-colonialism, with calls for the European Union to be given its own UN Security Council seat. In Britain the apologists maintain a lie that the EU is primarily about trade and economics, yet this subject highlights the ambition to make the EU a global power. We have calls for EU common positions on Security Council items and for Member States on the Council to act in the interests of the EU’s common security and foreign policy. This only expands the British people’s deep mistrust of the EU, and I feel safe in asserting that this attack, at the very heart of our own ability to define British foreign policy and security, is completely unacceptable. The time has come for the British people to vote to leave behind this 19th century answer to a 20th century problem and reaffirm our identity as a genuinely influential global trading nation. The world is our oyster, but inside the European Union, Britain’s future is as a clam.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I thank Mr Väyrynen for his report, which the European Commission takes as an encouragement for continuing to work for a strong European Union in the United Nations, as well as a strong partnership within the European Union and the United Nations. As High Representative and Vice-President Federica Mogherini stressed in Vienna, following the horrific attacks in Paris (which were, in fact, attacks on us all), the answer to these barbaric terrorists must be in joining forces and coming together. Now everybody is affected. After bombings in Lebanon, Turkey and Iraq, and the Russian plane crash, this is a global problem that requires a global response. The challenges we face today are truly global in nature, and effective world governance has never been so crucial. A strong, effective United Nations, as well as a strong, united European Union acting together to advance our foreign policy objectives, values and interests on the United Nations stage, are more essential than ever since its creation 70 years ago. The European Union has very close cooperation and frequent contacts with the United Nations Secretariat. On all main United Nations policies – peace and security, development of human rights – we support each other, ranging from humanitarian assistance to cooperation programmes to peace operations. Let us assure you that the European Union’s voice in the United Nations is strong and is clearly heard. Just to take two examples: first, the European Union spoke with a clear, united voice in the 2013 agenda negotiations and has thus had a major influence on this final outcome; second, the European Union regularly briefs the United Nations Security Council, including through High Representative Vice-President Federica Mogherini personally, and participates in United Nations Security Council debates. Many other United Nations member states regularly align with our statements, so we often speak on behalf of an even larger group than the European Union and its Member States. The European Union is appreciated as a reliable, positive and constructive partner, and often a bridge-builder. Strong European Union coordination allows us to appear as a solid and coherent political actor. It is more important than ever that we closely cooperate on the several crises we are faced with. The European Commission fully agrees with Members when they say that we need to take prevention and early action very seriously. Gender equality and women’s empowerment also remain one of our major common priorities in this context, and we pursue this very actively at the United Nations. While it can seem difficult when so many full-blown conflicts already demand attention, we cannot focus on symptoms alone. We must pay attention to drivers and the root causes of conflicts, extremism and forced migration. It is important to achieve not only a rhetorical shift but a change of mindset. A clear recognition of the close interlinkage between peace, sustainable development, governance, gender equality, human rights and the rule of law in the 2013 agenda for sustainable development was just last week discussed in the Security Council under the United Kingdom Presidency, where the European Union also delivered a statement. It is our conviction that the role of security and development actors should be complementary, and sustaining peace should be a unifying thread running through the work of the United Nations. We must preach peace, development and security, and we believe that, as a global framework agreed by all the United Nations member states, the 2013 agenda can help us to do this. The agenda is an important opportunity for all of us to depart from business as usual. It is also very relevant for the ongoing peace reviews. As Members will know, the United Nations is currently engaged in a period of strategic reflection on several levels, and we are following this with great interest in the European Union. Therefore, this report is very timely. It is absolutely essential that we keep up our regular exchanges between the European Union and the United Nations on so many levels, ranging from high-level exchanges to desk-to-desk dialogues, and this includes you, the Members of the European Parliament, who also regularly visit the United Nations capitals. Shared analysis together with our partners, including the United Nations, is essential for more joined—up strategic thinking. The attacks in Paris are a terrible reminder of the magnitude of the threat and the importance of joining forces on counter-terrorism. The European Union and the United Nations have decided on a number of actions in recent months, including on foreign fighters, terrorist financing and countering violent extremism. Our collective response cannot be a procedural exercise. It is clear that together we need to do more, more effectively, with a new sense of purpose and urgency. Solving the Syrian and Libyan conflicts clearly remains a top priority. High Representative and Vice-President Federica Mogherini quoted Robert Schuman in her statement congratulating the United Nations on its 70th anniversary one month ago. I quote: ‘World peace cannot be safeguarded without the making of creative efforts proportionate to the dangers which threaten it’.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Tuesday 24 November 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – The European Union's action at international level is based on the principles of democracy, the rule of law, equality, solidarity and the universal and indivisible nature of human rights and fundamental freedoms and respect for human dignity. I would like to recall that the principles and objectives of EU foreign policy are closely linked to the UN's objectives. The challenges facing the EU require global solutions and global problems require effective EU action. It therefore needs global partners to achieve its objectives, namely peace and security and preventing the spread of terrorism.  I am convinced that the Union must continue to strive to strengthen global governance within the UN. With regard to the migration and refugee crisis plaguing Europe, it is important to work more closely together to tackle the crisis and, among other things, to help remedy and sustainably develop the economic situation in the countries where migration begins.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I am pleased that Parliament's document on the role and cooperation of the European Union with the UN highlights the need to step up efforts involving sustainable cultural development and the protection and promotion of the diversity of cultural expressions by integrating education, tourism, cultural diplomacy, heritage protection, the creative sector and research into policy-making. As shadow rapporteur in the Committee on Culture, I emphasised, first of all, that culture should be supported for two reasons: as a tool for the European Union's external relations through intercultural and inter-religious dialogue and as an autothecal value to be played in itself. Moreover, it is important for me to draw up statistics on culture and the cultural sector, which will be used in the debate on cultural policy and to make it possible to emphasise more strongly the economic potential of the cultural and creative sectors and their impact on society, as well as to highlight the symbolic importance of cultural heritage, which, as the recent acts of destruction of cultural objects in Syria and Iraq have shown, has become a tool for achieving policy objectives. It is therefore necessary to step up efforts, coordinate more and raise public awareness in order to protect cultural heritage.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is one-minute speeches on significant political issues (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, 25 November this week marks International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women. Women are the primary victims of domestic abuse: physically, they are the weaker sex, and they are prone to this situation. I am pleased to inform this Parliament that the Irish State recently signed the Istanbul Convention of the Council of Europe on preventing and combating violence against women, and in particular domestic violence. Domestic violence has traditionally been viewed as something that goes on behind closed doors and should stay there. But this has changed, and we must continue to highlight cases and provide support to women – not necessarily just women who are victims of physical violence, but also abuse of a psychological nature, which can be even more sinister. Twelve to fifteen per cent of women in Europe face violence every day in their home. Our legal system, policing system and the judicial system in particular must be trained in issues of domestic violence and recognise it so that it is not seen as something that is merely for the domestic situation. Victims need to be supported, and the state services need to be fully aware of the implications of this situation.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, I would like to express my fellow citizens' concern about the escalation of violence, the increase in uncertainty and the fear of families for children who have gone to other countries. I have asked the Commission, but I would like to raise this serious issue in the plenary of Parliament relating to the safety of Europeans at home. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I consider it necessary for the President of the European Commission and the President of the Council to urgently present to Parliament and European citizens what the programme is on migration, refugees, border security and the security of the free movement of European citizens. Setting odds doesn't solve the problem. It is not possible to maintain a high degree of risk for a long time and there is a risk of losing lives.  Europeans want to know what the exit programme is. We want a united, secure European Union and legal treatment. We don't want any more two-speed Europe, we don't want any more uncertainty. All 28 states have signed an accession agreement and must benefit from the same rules and comply with the same rules.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We need to talk about the link between open borders, terror and security legislation. Mrs Hohlmeier shot the bird here last week. It has given the Greens and the left joint responsibility for the terrorist attacks in Paris, because they are opposed to greater surveillance of citizens. The terrorists have come over land. Passenger data storage does not help. Border controls would help. The terrorists coordinate with text messages, and the data retention of the French, which has been practiced for years, does not help – it has not used anything and a ban on encryption certainly has not helped either. The terrorists already have illegal weapons. It is a piece of the EU's great house that there is now a debate about tightening up the gun law for legal gun users and for sport shooters and hunters. The borders must be controlled, that is what the CSU and Mrs Hohlmeier do not want, and that is where the bunny is in the pepper.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Mr President, the war in Syria is a challenge for Europe, and the activities of ISIS are the most dangerous and imminent threat. The recent terrorist attacks in Paris and the tragic fate of the Russian plane in Egypt prove that the war has come to Europe. There were many concerns raised after the start of the Russians’ interference in Syria. We like to talk about differences in values with this country. However, from the perspective of ISIS, Europe and Russia are twins. ISIS is a danger not only because they are radicals or terrorists; ISIS has become an alternative project for the future of the Middle East and for the entire world. At the recent meeting in Palanga, the Baltic Presidents said they would not join any coalition fighting ISIS if it included Russia. It is not the first time that the Baltic States seek to evade their solidarity duties under this pretext. This approach is very wrong. We need to be united against a common enemy with all political actors, including Russia, Iran and others. The fight against ISIS is too important to abandon for geopolitical reasons.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – (2) Mr President, the situation of migrants on the Balkan route, in an unstoppable and significant flow, is of greatest humanitarian concern. This situation has worsened in recent days with the imposition by several countries of discriminatory and illegal barriers to the movement of persons on the basis of their nationality. Measures that add to acts of violence and extortion committed by the authorities on the destiture and vulnerable. An urgent response to this situation is needed. The only compaginable response is needed with some of the values and principles that the European Union likes to proclaim, but does not practice. The only commisable response to the human rights of those fleeing the misery, chaos and war that the European Union has helped sow and actively fuelled. In other words, the creation of safe and legal migratory routes that disarticulate trafficking networks that feed on repressive and criminalizing migration policies. And we also insist on the proposal for transfers of funds allocated to border surveillance for reception, support and social integration measures.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Mr President, we have just passed a date on 20 November, an emblematic date for the groups claiming the fascist dictatorship of Francisco Franco, and in many cities of the Spanish State public acts of vindication of that bloodthirsty regime have been held with total impunity.  Also in Alicante, where in 1977 Miquel Grau was killed by a fascist militant, who was later pardoned by the government. Finally, with the new municipal government, Miquel Grau has received the recognition she deserved, but this is an exception: there is still fascist exaltation and impunity and, moreover, systematic non-compliance with the Historical Memory Act, so the victims of that murderous dictatorship do not get the reparation they deserve.  Where are Commissioner Reding's words saying that the memory of crimes committed by totalitarian regimes must be preserved? Europe cannot remain silent in the face of the tolerance of one of its Member States – Spanish – towards totalitarianism. This Parliament and the rest of the European institutions must condemn this situation without mitigation and put pressure on the Spanish Government to fulfil its ethical and legal obligations. If we don't, we'll be complicit.

name: Margot PARKER
text: – Mr President, there is no more persecuted and yet more disregarded minority in the world than Christians. Over 90 countries ban or restrict Christian belief, many of them in the Middle East. For centuries Christians have lived, worked and prayed in the Middle East. Indeed, that region was the birthplace of Christianity. Yet since the collapse of secular leaders in the region, Islamists like ISIS have filled the vacuum with a toxic and intolerant campaign against Christians. We have seen ancient churches and monasteries looted and converted to mosques. In ISIS territory, Christian women and girls are sold in sex slave markets, whilst male Christians are forced to sign contracts that officially relegate them to second—class status. We also see the grotesque scenes of gay men and women being thrown off rooftops and kicked to death if they survive the fall. The silence of so many LGBT groups on this issue is puzzling. This hatred of gay men that is common in ISIS-style Islamic extremism is now spreading to my country, where gay men and women are frequently demonised in radical sermons. Violent attacks on gay men and women are a serious concern and totally unacceptable. East London, in particular, is a dangerous place for gay men. I hope whoever wins the London mayoral race – hopefully Peter Whittle, himself a gay man – will make tackling this problem a top priority.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, RDP, EFF, ESF, EFSI: between 2009 and 2015, hundreds of entrepreneurs, fishermen, farmers and trainers were seduced, deluded and then abandoned by the managing authorities of these programmes and funds. What I am describing is a more or less apocalyptic scenario that is taking place in my region, Sicily, where around 400 farms are at risk of closure if rdp funds planned for the period 2007-2013 are disengaged. That is why I have received a great many e-mails and requests from the people concerned, so that we can obtain an extension of the funds in question and, together with my parliamentary colleagues from the regional and national 5 Star Movement, I have tried to put as much pressure as possible on the national and regional authorities to request it. But the Commission has the final say. I therefore ask the Commission, with great humility, whether it is possible to obtain this extension, because it is vital for such an important sector for a region such as Sicily.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Mr President, Alzheimer's disease and related diseases affect around 6 million people in Europe and the number of new cases diagnosed each year continues to increase.  In France, 225,000 new cases are detected each year and one in four French people have a person around them, causing a great deal of suffering and distress, both for the person affected and for those around them.  This disease causes the gradual and irreversible loss of mental functions, including memory, and unfortunately there is currently no treatment for Alzheimer's disease, although some drug treatments may help slow down the process.  This disease, which is the leading cause of dependence in Europe, requires additional resources for research but, above all, to be recognised as a priority health issue in France and Europe. As such, I have tabled a written statement on this subject with twenty-four of my parliamentary colleagues of all political stripes, because it is the general and human interest that must take precedence. At this moment, I invite all Members of this Parliament to sign this declaration.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by On 13 January, I spoke in this parliament and said that our enemies are not in Moscow, but in mosques: not in Moscow but in mosques. This has been regarded as something awful by Mr Juncker, by Mr Schulz. I would like to ask if they do not think that, however, I was right, and they were wrong? I would also like to ask why saying that our enemies are in Moscow is not hate speech, but saying that our enemies are in mosques, that is hate speech? Finally, I would like to ask why Mr Schulz spoke today about the victims of terrorism and somehow did not name the victims of terrorism, where 204 passengers on a Russian plane were killed and only 130 people died in Paris? He didn't mention it. More besides, I believe that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: – Today is the 10th day of the monstrous attacks in Paris, but also the 321th day of the attack on the editorial office of Charlie Hebdo. If the blockade in Brussels is to show anything, it is that it cannot and is not possible to live in such a level of uncertainty and fear. So today, the 10th day of the Paris attacks, I stand before you to tell you that we cannot wait for it to be 321 days of this terrorist act to take action.    We have a few clear solutions ahead of us: First, to complete important dossiers such as that for the PASSENGER NAME RECORD Directive; strengthen key elements such as Frontex to make it a true guardian of the European Union's borders. Also decide what we do with radicalization and foreign fighters on our territory. Finally, to change the mechanisms at our borders so that we have enough information and be able to share it. Because every day without the necessary measures is a day of fear for our citizens.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Mr President, I note with concern that the idea of a so-called two-speed Europe has been at issue in recent times. It is all the more worrying because one of the leaders of the European Union, Mr Juncker, encourages such an idea that comes in direct opposition to the values and foundation of the European project based on cohesion, integration, bridging the gap. How can the Union fight effectively against key issues such as youth poverty or unemployment if it reduces integration? How can the European Union defend itself from external threats if its leaders consider fracturing? Such declarations, together with Britain's demands to restrict the rights of migrants, send an unwanted message in a difficult context, just when the Union needs solidarity and unity more than ever. I believe that the President of the Commission has a duty to make a statement because his vision is not at all clear. Neither what are the two speeds nor what rules they would see for a Europe that operates on this principle.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Mr President, honourable Members, the recent tragic events caused by the military attacks carried out by Islamic State on the territory of Member States of the European Union unequivocally confirm our concerns for a year and more about the invasion and attacks of The Salafit Sunni Islam and its terror in our homes. It is relentlessly clear that the European Union must immediately take the security and defence measures we offer at its external borders. To the south, the eu's largest land border is that of my homeland, the Republic of Bulgaria. And here I turn to my EPP and PES colleagues, those whom I consider responsible for the European Parliament's unintended and counterproductive behaviour towards Islamic State and terror. I again insist on the following immediate measures for the EU: an immediate cover-up of the state borders and at the border of the European Union, which falls to my homeland, the Republic of Bulgaria; immediate extradition and expulsion of all illegal immigrants from the territory of the EU and the Member States; the immediate physical detection, localisation and destruction of Islamist cells within the territory of the EU Member States. Dear Colleagues, Honourable Members, this is the only way we can at least try to protect our homes, our lives and what we accept as our values.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, today and now in Spain the families of nearly 100,000 missing continue to search for their relatives killed during the Franco dictatorship. They suffer the contempt of the Government, which allows, when it does not encourage, fascist tributes that should be crimes; blocking, with the support of the main opposition party, the prosecution of persons accused of crimes against humanity; maintained by the Cervantes Institute in Paris in what was the seat of the Basque Government in exile, seized by the Nazis and handed over to the dictator: humiliations for the victims of a criminal regime who find silence and passivity here. It is not yesterday's issues, they are today's injustices that we will continue to denounce here because they are a disgrace to the Union, which owes these victims the same attitude as that which prevented impunity from the murderers of other European totalitarian regimes.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: – Mr President, the European Union and the United Nations Human Rights Council have repeatedly spoken out against the denial, trivialisation or exaltation of the crimes of Francoism.  Today, however, there are still unacceptable situations in Europe, such as the continued payment by the German Government of pensions to Francoist blue division volunteers , as EH Bildu and Die Linke have just denounced before the European Commission – or as the Spanish Government's maintenance and protection of impunity for the crimes of the dictatorship , even today.  It's time to regain dignity, respect and memory for thousands of families who have been waiting for answers and justice for decades. This requires collective commitments and participatory processes, because historical memory belongs to all of us, and it is also the responsibility of this House to say loud and clear that with impunity there is no democracy, that in the face of the crimes of Francoism we demand justice and reparation.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, For years China has been invading our market with cheap products, which have already sent thousands of European workers home. But now Beijing is preparing the final attack and its accomplices are right here in Strasbourg and Brussels. If the Commission confirms this, China will be recognised as a market economy from December 2016 and we will no longer be able to use the protections with which we defend our products today.  But China is not a market economy. There is no legal obligation to recognise it as such and, above all, the choice cannot and must not belong only to the Commission, an unelected body. Do the citizens know that more than three million jobs in Europe depend on the choices of this body that no one has elected? Above all, does the Italian Government realise that 700 000 jobs, in Italy alone, depend on this decision?  Of course he knows. Everyone knows this, but everyone is silent: not even a tweet from our President-in-Office of the Council. No one in Italy talks about it, except Deputy Minister Calenda. But I wouldn't be surprised if collusive politics found a way to silence him. Perhaps 700,000 jobs are of no interest to anyone.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – A wave of migrants is flooding Europe. In more than a month, more than 250,000 people have travelled through Slovenia, which is more than 10% of the population of Slovenia, according to our police. However, only four asylum applications have been granted, so it can be assumed that most of them are economic migrants. Most of the people who come through our territory are undocumented. We are in Schengen and we have a duty to protect the European Union's external borders, but in several cases our police have detected people who have used the flow of migrants to return from combat zones in Syria. Especially in the light of the recent attacks in Paris, I am, of course, asking the European institutions what we are going to do. Can we trust our intelligence services and security measures? Are the human resources capacities sufficient and the security measures effective? I would also like to know, at what stage, after the recent events, the European Union's joint intelligence service project?

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Mr President, my first words today are to remind the victims of the latest terrorist attacks in Europe, which remind us of the need for a defence and security policy on our continent. In any case, I wanted to talk today about the decision, the debate on the possibility of granting China market economy status, a decision that could directly attack the industrial sector in Europe and very specifically affect very important sectors, such as the steel sector, with a very clear impact on my constituency, in Asturias. The Chinese economy is not a market economy. The credit is run by the state. The State prevents workers from mobility, preventing people from being able to move from one place to another in the country. What economy can be market with direct control of credit and people? This decision cannot be made in Europe, because it undermines steel, the industrial sector and regions like mine, such as Asturias, which have a very prosperous and very competitive future.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the SYRIZA-ANEL Memorandum Co-Government passed a few days ago another shameful law with prerequisites demanded by the troika and lenders: The main cutting edge of the law is red loans. The Greek banks with the successive recapitalisations that have taken place should have long since written off many red loans, because they have received funds for this purpose.  Instead, the implementation of the regulations of this law will lead to tens of thousands of foreclosures and auctions of greek borrowers' homes and international for-profit credit institutions, various funds and crows, will put their hands on the homes of Greek citizens.  Such a law had not even dared to vote that previous memorial governments. This is precisely what the SYRIZA ANEL mnemonic co-government voted for, unfortunately. The Greek citizens will fight peacefully and democratically and we will not allow any of our compatriots to lose their home, as happened in Spain. No house in the hands of a banker. No house for crows.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: - Mr. President, the Common Foreign and Security Policy has existed for 25 years and a common security and defence policy for a full 15 years. In this past, both policies have developed their mechanisms, activities, forms of action and bodies, but there has been no significant shift in terms of the unity and strength of the two policies.  Crises facing the European Union, easusing wars, refugees and terrorism would be much easier to resolve and some of them even prevented with a stronger common foreign security or defence policy.  After the past 15 and 25 years of experience, especially the latest painful experience with poor crisis response, it is clear that the common foreign security and defence policy needs to be strengthened, as there is no reason to hope that the challenges facing the European Union will be smaller and easier in the future.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, last week saw a significant agreement made by the two largest political parties in the North of Ireland and with the Irish and British Governments. The six counties’ institutions are the only viable platform to give protection to the working poor and those on benefits. Last week, however, did not see the British Government address breaches of its Article 2 obligations under the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) – the right to life – which the ECHR found that Britain had violated during the conflict in Ireland. The British Government has covered up for state actors, their agents, the British army, police and the political institutions which colluded in countless murders, and to this day the British Government continues to exercise a national security veto to conceal the role it played in collusion in Ireland. The Council of Europe’s Commissioner for Human Rights, Mr Muižnieks, must return to Belfast to investigate Britain’s role in the conflict and its human rights abuses and to bring the British Government to book for acting with impunity, and to work with the families to get full disclosure of information for the victims and the families.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: – Mr President, my first words are in memory of the victims of Paris, Beirut, Bamako, Nigeria. Assuming that history is a science and that memory is subjective, the truth is that the passage of time establishes irrefutable certainties. One of those is that last Friday he made forty years of the death of dictator Francisco Franco. Another, that his crimes go unpunished; and, to speak of specific people, another certainty is that in 2013 he made seventy-five years of the shooting of Manuel Carrasco i Formiguera, leader of my party, Unió Democratica de Catalunya. A convinced Christian, a Catalan to the core, had to leave Catalonia for being persecuted for those uncontrolled by his religious ideas and, arriving in the Basque Country, he fell to the insurrect factional army, who subjected him to great trial and shot him on 9 April 1938 for his insobable commitment to democracy, freedom and the Catalan nation. Spanish democracy and, by extension, European democracy still pass the shame of not having restored their dignity and that of so many thousands of people with similar stories, nullified all those summary trials. Their dignity, and with theirs that of their families and that of all of us, is pending. For the record.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Mr. President, the issue of border protection in the European Union has become dramatically linked to the issue of protecting citizens over the past weeks. So far, the refugee phenomenon has been largely treated as a humanitarian and organisational issue, and after the Massacre in Paris and the events in Brussels it receives primarily a security profile. The EU is in a special kind of war. And part of the Civil War. Europe was not attacked by any foreign armies, but it is brutally being attacked by some of its nationals who were born and raised here. The roots of this phenomenon should be sought in the type of social pathology created by the feeling of exclusion from the systems that were supposed to ensure social promotion and acceptance. Of course everyone who gets hit by unemployment doesn't automatically become a terrorist. This is about pervading various social, foreign policy, religious and media factors. But there is no doubt that terrorist threats will shug not only national, but also European and global institutions by determining the character of the European Union in the first decades of the 21st century.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: – Mr President, the clear effort of international terrorism today is to push some of the conflict surface into Europe, and precisely during the Christmas holiday season. They want to unsaly and intimidate the citizens of Europe. I am concerned that many people in this Parliament are underestimating the seriousness of this situation. I am convinced that the citizens of Europe expect action from us, and we must take these decisions if we are to maintain citizens' trust in the European Union. We should not be playing the classic political games here, it should not be a question of who defeats whom, but of finding reasonable solutions to the situation.  The European People's Party has developed a package of solutions to increase the security of Europe's citizens. I would like to ask honourable colleagues to study this material so that we can adopt its elements as soon as possible. Otherwise, there are fears that citizens will listen to the words of political extremists.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, despite the seriousness of the situation concerning the security of our citizens, the European project must continue. We must not let these moments of crisis overwhelm us or mask our inaction on a problem concerning the European future, namely the lack of jobs among young people. Even if we often forget to talk about young people and the many vulnerabilities of this category, this does not mean that the problems no longer exist. On the contrary, they are getting worse. Today there are still 4.6 million young Europeans without any occupation whatsoever. The European Commission needs to come up with concrete data on the implementation of programmes aimed at preparing and occupying young people, and we in the European Parliament need to convince our institutional partners that we need more major initiatives and investments to reduce youth unemployment. That is why we have proposed that these programmes should also apply to young people up to the age of 35. As such, this issue must not disappear from our agenda and from public discourse because the lack of a solution will affect our long-term well-being.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, the Helsinki Final Act on respect for human rights, including the rights of minorities, was adopted 40 years ago and the Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities was signed here in Strasbourg 20 years ago. This double anniversary is therefore a good opportunity to draw a balance sheet and to conclude that there is still a great deal of work to be done in putting in place and applying the minority protection passages of international conventions. Many of the points of the Framework Agreement are simply not being implemented, and in my view, it could help if the Institutions of the European Union adopted a legally binding framework for the protection of minorities.  Although we would expect the initiative from the Commission, Parliament, as a representative of the interests of European citizens, could also lead this process. 40 million EU citizens are directly affected by this issue, so the EU must address the problems of national minorities. All the more so since Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union states that the Union is based on respect for the rights of minorities.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, we have only 25 minutes left to vote and decide on the winner of the 10th edition of the Lux Film Prize, which will be announced tomorrow in plenary of the European Parliament.  I mention this because the language of film is sometimes much easier for citizens to understand than the language of us politicians. And these films that have been nominated are very topical. The film Mediterranea talks about the motivation and fate of African refugees. The film Mustang talks about a young generation of Turks, and the Bulgarian film Urok talks about family relationships, misunderstandings and conflicts. These are films that are of great value and which contribute to dialogue between Europeans, which also contribute to the debate on European values between us, politicians and the citizens of the European Union. I believe that this prize also contributes to a greater awareness of the European values that we are supposed to defend here.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, this week the first snow fell at home as autumn rapidly moves to winter. For many people this brings the added dread of extra energy costs. Energy efficiency and renewables are a key means of ensuring that energy poverty is reduced long term. While much progress has been made on improving efficiency and reducing their cost, government support schemes remain crucial. The market alone cannot deliver this crucial investment, particularly for those living in social housing and the private rental sector. That is why the recent decision by the Tories to slash support for solar and onshore wind is such a deplorable act. With the right legal framework, solar power alone could generate GBP 25.6 billion for the UK economy and support over 8 000 full—time skilled jobs – a vital investment in our future, putting money into local communities like my own. The UK Government should – and must – reverse its short—term and short—sighted decision.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Mr President, the question of the recognition of China's status as a market economy is a matter of debate, as we have seen this evening. It would have a strong impact on employment in our economy, not least because China has a clearly aggressive trade policy. These fears are particularly important in the steel sector, where bosses and unions have the same view.  China is not a market economy, it floods our market with steel products at prices that do not respect the principles of fair competition. To recognize it as such would therefore be detrimental to hundreds of thousands of direct and indirect jobs, and more generally to our economy as a whole. To be recognized as a market economy in the European Union, China must comply with five technical criteria, but they are far from being met. We must defend the values of our socially regulated market economy and not grant this status to China. It is a question of vitality and future for our economy, but above all for our industry and its jobs.

name: István UJHELYI
text: "Mr President, it is slowly 3/4 11 p.m. above the European flags, and I have once again waited for this time with diligence because I have to say that I have to understand something with everyone. I know there's a lot of fear in all of us because of acts of terrorism. I know that there are governments, political forces, who have used the past to spread anti-refugee propaganda. But let us understand that the real problem is in today's European society. And that's why I need to talk about child poverty. Currently, 26 million children in Europe are poor, with one in four children living in poverty. In Hungary, the figure is an awful 41.4%. I must tell you that we need to do something about this, and that is why I am calling your attention to the fact that tomorrow we are voting on the decision to end child poverty, and then governments should take note of the need to implement the common will, to end child poverty together, so that there will be no healthy development in Europe.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the discussion on this item on the agenda.
